article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
passage_text:
Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
    
    
        There once was a poor boy named Aladdin. His father worked as a tailor, making clothes for people. When his father died, Aladdin's mother had to work hard to earn money for food and shelter.One day, a stranger walked up to Aladdin on the street. "Tell me, young man," said the stranger. "Are you the son of the tailor who lived here?""Yes, I am," said Aladdin.The stranger threw his arms around Aladdin and hugged him tight. "My dear nephew!" he cried out. "Your father was my brother! Now I learn that he has died! What terrible news!"

---

Aladdin brought the man home to meet his mother. She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother. Even so, she welcomed the man into their home. When the stranger promised to help Aladdin learn to become a merchant and earn good money, she believed his words.But the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all. He was actually a powerful magician who had traveled from far away in North Africa. He had come all the way to Persia to search for a special magic lamp. People said this lamp had amazing powers that would make any person very rich. To find this lamp, the magician needed someone to help him. He wanted to find a person who would follow his directions without asking too many questions. He thought Aladdin was exactly the right person for this job.

---

The next morning, the magician came to Aladdin's house. "Come with me today," he said to the boy. "I want to introduce you to other merchants in the city." Then he led Aladdin away from town and out into the countryside.The magician took Aladdin up a very steep mountain path. They climbed higher and higher for a whole hour. Finally, they reached a spot where no flowers or plants could grow. The ground looked empty and bare."Go gather some dry sticks," the magician told Aladdin. "We will build a fire here. Then I will show you something truly amazing."Aladdin did exactly what the man asked him to do. The magician lit the fire with the sticks. Then he threw sweet-smelling perfumes into the flames and spoke magical words in a loud voice. Suddenly, the bright sky turned dark like night. Thunder crashed and rumbled all around them. The earth split open right at their feet. There in front of them lay a huge stone with a brass ring attached to it.

---

"Under this heavy stone lies a great treasure," said the magician. "It will make you richer than any king in the world. Lift the stone by pulling on the ring. Then go down the stairs. You will see many treasures as you walk, but you must not touch any of them. You will come to a beautiful garden. In that garden, you will see a lamp hanging from a tree. Bring that lamp back to me. Once you have the lamp, you may take any treasures you want."Aladdin felt amazed by what he heard. He could hardly believe what the magician was asking him to do. But he agreed to help."Take this special ring," said the magician. "It will keep you safe from any harm." Aladdin took the ring and put it on his finger. Then he pulled the heavy stone up by its brass ring and went down into the dark cave below.Aladdin found the lamp and filled his bag with beautiful gems. But all those gems made his bag very heavy. When he climbed back to the top of the stairs, he could not pull himself out of the cave opening."Give me your hand, Uncle," Aladdin called out. "Help me climb out!""First, hand me the lamp," the magician answered back.The lamp was buried deep in Aladdin's heavy bag. "I cannot reach it right now," Aladdin said.The magician grew very angry. He only cared about getting the magic lamp. When Aladdin said he would give it to him after climbing out, the impatient magician could not wait any longer. He spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place. Poor Aladdin was trapped in the dark cave below.
question: In the story, the magician tells Aladdin that finding the lamp will make him "richer than any king in the world."What does this phrase mean?
option_1: Aladdin will have more money than he can count
option_2: Aladdin will become the ruler of a kingdom
option_3: Aladdin will find gold coins in the cave
option_4: Aladdin will meet kings from other countries
option_1_explanation: You successfully made a good prediction by using clues about the magic lamp and treasure. The text supports this when it says the lamp “had amazing powers that would make any person very rich” and the magician promises it “will make you richer than any king in the world.” Remember to look for repeated hints and strong words like “will” to predict what will happen next.
option_2_explanation: You may have thought “richer than any king” means Aladdin becomes a king, or you used what you know from other versions, but the text says the lamp “would make any person very rich” and “It will make you richer than any king,” which is about money, not ruling. So the correct answer is that Aladdin will have more money than he can count. Strategy: Reread and underline clue words like “rich/richer,” and choose the answer that matches exactly what the passage says—not what you expect from outside the story.
option_3_explanation: You may have brought in outside ideas (gold coins), but the text never mentions coins—Aladdin finds “beautiful gems,” and the lamp is said to make a person “very rich,” even “richer than any king.” That means the best prediction is about how much wealth he will have, not a specific kind of money, so “Aladdin will have more money than he can count” fits the text. Next time, stick to the exact words and look for clue phrases about the main idea, like “very rich.”
option_4_explanation: You may have focused on the word “king” and guessed he’d meet kings, but the text never says Aladdin will meet any kings; it says the lamp “had amazing powers that would make any person very rich” and the treasure “will make you richer than any king in the world.” That evidence points to the correct answer: Aladdin will have more money than he can count. Strategy: reread for clue words and choose the option that matches what the passage actually says, not ideas it doesn’t mention.

question: What does the phrase 'the earth split open' describe in the story?
option_1: The ground cracked apart to reveal a hidden entrance
option_2: An earthquake happened on top of the mountain
option_3: The magician dug a deep hole in the dirt
option_4: Lightning struck the ground and made a crater
option_1_explanation: Correct! The text says 'The earth split open right at their feet' and then 'There in front of them lay a huge stone with a brass ring.' This phrase describes how the ground magically opened to show the entrance to the cave below. This is nonliteral language showing something magical happened.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. While 'split open' might make you think of an earthquake, the text shows this was caused by the magician's spell, not a natural earthquake. The phrase is describing a magical event, not a natural disaster.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The magician did not dig anything. The text says he 'spoke magical words' and then 'the earth split open,' which means magic caused the ground to open, not physical digging.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. While the text mentions 'Thunder crashed and rumbled,' it does not say lightning struck the ground. The phrase 'earth split open' describes the magical opening of the ground to reveal the stone covering the cave entrance.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 3 magical event description - differs from reference which asks about wealth phrase in paragraph 4
homogeneity_check: all choices are physical ground events or phenomena
specificity_check: all describe specific ground-related actions with similar detail
length_check: A: 10 words, B: 8 words, C: 9 words, D: 9 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: distinct concepts: magical opening vs earthquake vs digging vs lightning strike
single_correct_check: only A matches the text's magical revelation of hidden entrance
diversity_check: targets paragraph 3 magical event, uses nonliteral descriptive phrase - completely different from reference wealth metaphor

question: According to the first paragraph, what does it mean that Aladdin's mother had to 'work hard to earn money'?
option_1: She had to do difficult jobs to pay for their needs
option_2: She had to learn how to make clothes like a tailor
option_3: She had to ask strangers to give her family money
option_4: She had to travel far away to find a better job
option_1_explanation: Correct! The text explains that after Aladdin's father died, 'Aladdin's mother had to work hard to earn money for food and shelter.' This phrase means she needed to do challenging work to get the money they needed to survive. The phrase 'work hard' is literal language meaning to put in great effort at a job.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. The text does not say she became a tailor. It says his father 'worked as a tailor,' but we do not know what job the mother did. The phrase means she had to do difficult work, not specifically tailoring.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. 'Work hard to earn money' means doing a job to get paid, not asking for money. Earning means getting money by working, which is different from asking people to give you money.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The text does not mention her traveling anywhere. The phrase 'work hard to earn money' describes putting effort into a job, not traveling to find one. She stayed and worked to support her family after her husband died.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 1 family circumstances - differs from reference which asks about magician's wealth promise in paragraph 4

specificity_check: all describe specific ways of obtaining income with similar detail

question: What does the magician mean when he says the lamp 'had amazing powers that would make any person very rich'?
option_1: The lamp was made of expensive gold and jewels
option_2: The lamp contained magical abilities to create great wealth
option_3: The lamp could light up dark caves to find treasure
option_4: The lamp was very old and worth money to collectors
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. The text says the lamp 'had amazing powers,' which tells us the lamp itself was magical, not that it was made of expensive materials. The phrase is about what the lamp can do, not what it is made from.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The text explains the magician wanted 'a special magic lamp' and 'People said this lamp had amazing powers that would make any person very rich.' This nonliteral phrase means the lamp had supernatural or magical abilities that could create wealth for whoever owned it, not just that it was valuable.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. While lamps do provide light, the phrase 'amazing powers that would make any person very rich' is describing magical abilities to create wealth, not just the normal function of lighting dark places.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The text emphasizes 'amazing powers' which indicates magic, not just being valuable because of age. The phrase is about the lamp's supernatural abilities to make someone wealthy, not its value as an antique.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 2 magician's motivation about lamp's powers - differs from reference which asks about 'richer than any king' comparison in paragraph 4

specificity_check: all provide specific reasons for the lamp's worth with similar detail

single_correct_check: only B correctly identifies the nonliteral magical powers meaning

question: Based on paragraph 3, what does the phrase 'the ground looked empty and bare' tell us about the location?
option_1: Nothing was growing or living in that place
option_2: The magician had cleared away all the plants earlier
option_3: A fire had burned down all the trees recently
option_4: The mountain was covered with snow and ice
option_1_explanation: Correct! The text says 'they reached a spot where no flowers or plants could grow. The ground looked empty and bare.' This phrase uses descriptive language to show that the place was lifeless and nothing grew there. 'Empty and bare' means there was nothing living or growing on the ground.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. The text does not say the magician cleared plants away. The phrase 'empty and bare' describes the natural state of this location - that plants could not grow there at all, not that someone removed them.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. There is no mention of a previous fire. The text explains 'no flowers or plants could grow' in this spot, meaning it was naturally barren, not that something destroyed plants that once grew there.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The text does not mention snow or ice. 'Empty and bare' means without plants or life, not covered with snow. The description is about the lack of vegetation, not about weather or snow cover.

But he agreed to help."Take this special ring," said the magician. "It will keep you safe from any harm." Aladdin took the ring and put it on his finger. Then he pulled the heavy stone up by its brass ring and went down into the dark cave below.Aladdin found the lamp and filled his bag with beautiful gems. But all those gems made his bag very heavy. When he climbed back to the top of the stairs, he could not pull himself out of the cave opening."Give me your hand, Uncle," Aladdin called out. "Help me climb out!""First, hand me the lamp," the magician answered back.The lamp was buried deep in Aladdin's heavy bag. "I cannot reach it right now," Aladdin said.The magician grew very angry. He only cared about getting the magic lamp. When Aladdin said he would give it to him after climbing out, the impatient magician could not wait any longer. He spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place. Poor Aladdin was trapped in the dark cave below.
question: What causes the magician to trap Aladdin in the cave?
option_1: Aladdin doesn't give him the lamp right away.
option_2: Aladdin won't to go into the cave.
option_3: Aladdin takes too many gems from the cave.
option_4: Aladdin breaks the magic ring on his finger.
option_1_explanation: You successfully understood cause and effect by noticing that Aladdin doesn’t give the lamp right away. The text supports this when the magician says, “First, hand me the lamp,” and Aladdin replies, “I cannot reach it right now.” Remember to reread what happens right before and after an event to see why it happens.
option_2_explanation: You may have thought Aladdin refused to go into the cave, but the story says he “agreed to help” and “went down into the dark cave below.” The problem is that “the lamp was buried deep in Aladdin’s heavy bag,” so he couldn’t reach it and didn’t give it to the magician right away—that’s why the correct answer is “Aladdin doesn’t give him the lamp right away.” Next time, reread and find the exact sentence in the text that answers the question.
option_3_explanation: You may have focused on the gems, but the text shows the problem happens when Aladdin won’t give the lamp right away: “First, hand me the lamp… The magician grew very angry,” and then he seals the cave. So the correct answer is that Aladdin doesn’t hand over the lamp right away. Next time, reread the sentences just before the trouble to find the real cause.
option_4_explanation: You may have brought in an idea that isn’t in this part of the story (the ring breaking), but look at the text: “First, hand me the lamp…,” “I cannot reach it right now,” and “The magician grew very angry,” which shows he’s mad because Aladdin doesn’t give him the lamp right away. The passage never says the ring breaks; it only says the ring will keep him safe. To find the right answer, reread the lines around the event and look for cause-and-effect clue words (like “first,” “when”), and choose the option that matches what the text directly says.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
passage_text:
Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
    
    
        There once was a poor boy named Aladdin. His father worked as a tailor, making clothes for people. When his father died, Aladdin's mother had to work hard to earn money for food and shelter.One day, a stranger walked up to Aladdin on the street. "Tell me, young man," said the stranger. "Are you the son of the tailor who lived here?""Yes, I am," said Aladdin.The stranger threw his arms around Aladdin and hugged him tight. "My dear nephew!" he cried out. "Your father was my brother! Now I learn that he has died! What terrible news!"

---

Aladdin brought the man home to meet his mother. She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother. Even so, she welcomed the man into their home. When the stranger promised to help Aladdin learn to become a merchant and earn good money, she believed his words.But the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all. He was actually a powerful magician who had traveled from far away in North Africa. He had come all the way to Persia to search for a special magic lamp. People said this lamp had amazing powers that would make any person very rich. To find this lamp, the magician needed someone to help him. He wanted to find a person who would follow his directions without asking too many questions. He thought Aladdin was exactly the right person for this job.

---

The next morning, the magician came to Aladdin's house. "Come with me today," he said to the boy. "I want to introduce you to other merchants in the city." Then he led Aladdin away from town and out into the countryside.The magician took Aladdin up a very steep mountain path. They climbed higher and higher for a whole hour. Finally, they reached a spot where no flowers or plants could grow. The ground looked empty and bare."Go gather some dry sticks," the magician told Aladdin. "We will build a fire here. Then I will show you something truly amazing."Aladdin did exactly what the man asked him to do. The magician lit the fire with the sticks. Then he threw sweet-smelling perfumes into the flames and spoke magical words in a loud voice. Suddenly, the bright sky turned dark like night. Thunder crashed and rumbled all around them. The earth split open right at their feet. There in front of them lay a huge stone with a brass ring attached to it.

---

"Under this heavy stone lies a great treasure," said the magician. "It will make you richer than any king in the world. Lift the stone by pulling on the ring. Then go down the stairs. You will see many treasures as you walk, but you must not touch any of them. You will come to a beautiful garden. In that garden, you will see a lamp hanging from a tree. Bring that lamp back to me. Once you have the lamp, you may take any treasures you want."Aladdin felt amazed by what he heard. He could hardly believe what the magician was asking him to do. But he agreed to help."Take this special ring," said the magician. "It will keep you safe from any harm." Aladdin took the ring and put it on his finger. Then he pulled the heavy stone up by its brass ring and went down into the dark cave below.Aladdin found the lamp and filled his bag with beautiful gems. But all those gems made his bag very heavy. When he climbed back to the top of the stairs, he could not pull himself out of the cave opening."Give me your hand, Uncle," Aladdin called out. "Help me climb out!""First, hand me the lamp," the magician answered back.The lamp was buried deep in Aladdin's heavy bag. "I cannot reach it right now," Aladdin said.The magician grew very angry. He only cared about getting the magic lamp. When Aladdin said he would give it to him after climbing out, the impatient magician could not wait any longer. He spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place. Poor Aladdin was trapped in the dark cave below.
question: What shows that the magician's real goal is to get the lamp, not to help Aladdin?
option_1: He traps Aladdin when the boy cannot give him the lamp immediately
option_2: He gives Aladdin a magic ring to keep him safe in the cave
option_3: He takes Aladdin away from the city to climb a mountain
option_4: He tells Aladdin's mother that he wants to help the boy
option_1_explanation: Correct! The text shows the magician 'only cared about getting the magic lamp' and when Aladdin could not hand it over right away, 'He spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place. Poor Aladdin was trapped.' This action reveals his true selfish motivation - he traps Aladdin rather than helping him, showing he never cared about the boy.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. Giving Aladdin the ring might seem helpful, but the text explains the magician 'needed someone to help him' get the lamp. He protected Aladdin only so the boy could complete the task, not because he truly cared about helping him.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Taking Aladdin to the mountain was necessary to reach the lamp's location, not evidence of his real goal. The text shows his true motivation later when he traps Aladdin for not giving him the lamp fast enough.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. What he told the mother was part of his deception. The text says 'the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all' and he lied to gain trust. His words do not show his real goal - his actions of trapping Aladdin do.
differentiation_notes: Targets final paragraph climax action - differs from reference which asks general causal question about trapping
homogeneity_check: all choices are actions or statements by the magician
specificity_check: all cite specific events from the story with similar detail
length_check: A: 12 words, B: 12 words, C: 11 words, D: 12 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: distinct evidence: trapping action vs protective ring vs mountain journey vs false promises
single_correct_check: only A shows clear evidence of selfish motivation over helping
diversity_check: targets last paragraph's revelation through action, requires analyzing contradiction between words and deeds - different from reference simple cause question

question: How do the magician's actions in the beginning of the story lead to Aladdin getting trapped?
option_1: The magician lies about being family so Aladdin will trust and obey him
option_2: The magician teaches Aladdin how to use magic spells incorrectly
option_3: The magician forces Aladdin to steal gems from the cave
option_4: The magician tells Aladdin's mother to send her son away
option_1_explanation: Correct! The text shows the magician 'was not really Aladdin's uncle at all' but pretended to be family. He 'wanted to find a person who would follow his directions without asking too many questions.' By lying about being family, he gained trust so Aladdin would obey him and go into the cave. This deception at the beginning leads directly to Aladdin being trapped when he cannot immediately give the lamp.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. The magician does not teach Aladdin any magic. The text shows the magician performed magic himself and gave Aladdin a protective ring, but he never taught the boy how to use spells. Aladdin gets trapped because of the magician's impatience, not incorrect magic use.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The magician did not force Aladdin to take gems. The text says 'Once you have the lamp, you may take any treasures you want,' giving Aladdin permission. Aladdin chose to fill his bag with gems, which made it heavy, but the magician's impatience about getting the lamp caused the trapping.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The text shows the mother 'welcomed the man into their home' and 'believed his words,' but he did not tell her to send Aladdin away. He deceived both of them by pretending to be family, and this deception enabled everything that followed.
differentiation_notes: Targets cause-effect chain from paragraph 2 deception through paragraph 5 consequence - differs from reference immediate cause question
homogeneity_check: all choices are actions the magician took involving Aladdin
specificity_check: all describe specific cause-effect relationships with similar detail

question: Based on the story, why does the magician choose Aladdin specifically instead of going into the cave himself?
option_1: He needs someone young who will follow orders without questioning
option_2: He is too old and weak to climb down into the cave
option_3: He believes only someone from Persia can touch the lamp
option_4: He wants to teach Aladdin how to become rich first
option_1_explanation: Correct! The text explains that 'To find this lamp, the magician needed someone to help him. He wanted to find a person who would follow his directions without asking too many questions. He thought Aladdin was exactly the right person for this job.' The magician chose Aladdin because he could manipulate a poor boy into obeying him completely.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. The text never suggests the magician is too weak. In fact, he climbs the steep mountain with Aladdin. The text clearly states he needed someone 'who would follow his directions without asking too many questions,' not someone to do physical work he could not do.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The text does not mention any rule about only people from Persia touching the lamp. The magician came 'from far away in North Africa' specifically to find the lamp, so location is not the reason he needed help.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The magician's promise to help Aladdin become a merchant was a lie to gain trust. The text says 'the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all' and he only wanted 'to get the lamp.' Teaching Aladdin was never his real goal.

question: What evidence from the story shows that the magician never intended to help Aladdin become wealthy?
option_1: He becomes angry and traps Aladdin instead of helping him out of the cave
option_2: He travels from North Africa to Persia searching for the lamp
option_3: He brings Aladdin to a remote mountain instead of the city marketplace
option_4: He gives Aladdin a special protective ring before entering the cave
option_1_explanation: Correct! The text states 'The magician grew very angry. He only cared about getting the magic lamp.' When Aladdin needed help climbing out, the magician demanded the lamp first. When Aladdin could not give it immediately, the magician 'spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place,' trapping him. A person who truly wanted to help Aladdin become wealthy would have helped him out of the cave, but instead the magician abandoned him when he did not get what he wanted.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. His long journey shows his determination to find the lamp for himself, but does not directly prove he would not help Aladdin. The clearest evidence of his true intentions comes from his actions when Aladdin needs help - he traps the boy instead of assisting him.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Going to the mountain was necessary because that is where the lamp was hidden. This does not prove he would not help Aladdin - he needed to go there to get the lamp. His trapping of Aladdin at the end provides the strongest evidence of his selfish intentions.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Giving Aladdin the ring might seem like he was helping, but the text explains he needed Aladdin safe to retrieve the lamp. The ring served the magician's purpose. The real evidence of his selfishness is when he traps Aladdin rather than helping him out of the cave.

question: What is the central message or lesson of this story about Aladdin and the magician?
option_1: Magic can solve all of your problems if you believe in it.
option_2: Be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises.
option_3: Hard work is the only way to become wealthy and successful.
option_4: Always listen to your mother's advice about strangers.
option_1_explanation: You may have focused on the word “magic,” but look at how the magician lies about being Aladdin’s uncle, promises riches, and then uses magic to trap Aladdin in the cave—believing in magic doesn’t solve his problems, it creates them. This shows the real lesson is to be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises. Next time, check that your answer matches what happens in the whole story, especially the results of the characters’ actions.
option_2_explanation: You successfully identified the lesson by noticing how a stranger’s big promises led to trouble. The text supports this when the man promises to help Aladdin “learn to become a merchant and earn good money” and says the treasure will make him “richer than any king in the world,” but then he traps Aladdin in the cave. Remember, when finding a story’s lesson, ask yourself, “What happens after a character makes a big promise?”
option_3_explanation: You may have focused on the detail that Aladdin’s mother works hard, but the story’s events point to a different lesson. Aladdin doesn’t become rich through hard work—the stranger pretends to be his uncle, promises to make him a merchant, then uses magic and traps Aladdin in the cave to get the lamp. This shows the real lesson: be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises. Strategy: Reread the whole passage and ask, “What warning does the story give?” so your answer matches the main message, not just one detail.
option_4_explanation: You might be thinking about what parents usually say about strangers, but in the story the mother doesn’t give advice—she believes the “uncle,” and he is really a magician. The man promises Aladdin he will “earn good money” and find a treasure “richer than any king,” then he tricks Aladdin and traps him, so the lesson is to be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises. Next time, reread and ask, “What lesson fits what actually happens in the whole story?”

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
passage_text:
Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
    
    
        There once was a poor boy named Aladdin. His father worked as a tailor, making clothes for people. When his father died, Aladdin's mother had to work hard to earn money for food and shelter.One day, a stranger walked up to Aladdin on the street. "Tell me, young man," said the stranger. "Are you the son of the tailor who lived here?""Yes, I am," said Aladdin.The stranger threw his arms around Aladdin and hugged him tight. "My dear nephew!" he cried out. "Your father was my brother! Now I learn that he has died! What terrible news!"

---

Aladdin brought the man home to meet his mother. She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother. Even so, she welcomed the man into their home. When the stranger promised to help Aladdin learn to become a merchant and earn good money, she believed his words.But the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all. He was actually a powerful magician who had traveled from far away in North Africa. He had come all the way to Persia to search for a special magic lamp. People said this lamp had amazing powers that would make any person very rich. To find this lamp, the magician needed someone to help him. He wanted to find a person who would follow his directions without asking too many questions. He thought Aladdin was exactly the right person for this job.

---

The next morning, the magician came to Aladdin's house. "Come with me today," he said to the boy. "I want to introduce you to other merchants in the city." Then he led Aladdin away from town and out into the countryside.The magician took Aladdin up a very steep mountain path. They climbed higher and higher for a whole hour. Finally, they reached a spot where no flowers or plants could grow. The ground looked empty and bare."Go gather some dry sticks," the magician told Aladdin. "We will build a fire here. Then I will show you something truly amazing."Aladdin did exactly what the man asked him to do. The magician lit the fire with the sticks. Then he threw sweet-smelling perfumes into the flames and spoke magical words in a loud voice. Suddenly, the bright sky turned dark like night. Thunder crashed and rumbled all around them. The earth split open right at their feet. There in front of them lay a huge stone with a brass ring attached to it.

---

"Under this heavy stone lies a great treasure," said the magician. "It will make you richer than any king in the world. Lift the stone by pulling on the ring. Then go down the stairs. You will see many treasures as you walk, but you must not touch any of them. You will come to a beautiful garden. In that garden, you will see a lamp hanging from a tree. Bring that lamp back to me. Once you have the lamp, you may take any treasures you want."Aladdin felt amazed by what he heard. He could hardly believe what the magician was asking him to do. But he agreed to help."Take this special ring," said the magician. "It will keep you safe from any harm." Aladdin took the ring and put it on his finger. Then he pulled the heavy stone up by its brass ring and went down into the dark cave below.Aladdin found the lamp and filled his bag with beautiful gems. But all those gems made his bag very heavy. When he climbed back to the top of the stairs, he could not pull himself out of the cave opening."Give me your hand, Uncle," Aladdin called out. "Help me climb out!""First, hand me the lamp," the magician answered back.The lamp was buried deep in Aladdin's heavy bag. "I cannot reach it right now," Aladdin said.The magician grew very angry. He only cared about getting the magic lamp. When Aladdin said he would give it to him after climbing out, the impatient magician could not wait any longer. He spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place. Poor Aladdin was trapped in the dark cave below.
question: What lesson does this story teach about accepting help from people you just met?
option_1: Strangers who offer easy money may have hidden reasons for helping you
option_2: Family members always tell the truth about their identity
option_3: Poor people should accept any help offered to them
option_4: Magic can help you solve problems if you trust the right person
option_1_explanation: Correct! The story shows how the magician lied about being Aladdin's uncle and promised to help him become rich, but really only wanted the lamp for himself. The text says 'the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all' and shows he trapped Aladdin when he did not get what he wanted. The central lesson is to be cautious about strangers who make big promises because they may be trying to use you, just like the reference question teaches.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. This story actually teaches the opposite - the magician lied about being family! The text clearly states 'the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all' and 'She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother.' The lesson is about being careful, not about trusting family claims.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The story shows that accepting help without questioning can be dangerous. Aladdin accepted the magician's help and ended up trapped in a cave. The lesson is to be cautious and thoughtful, not to accept all help offered.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Magic is not the lesson here. The magician used magic to trap Aladdin, not help him. The story teaches about being careful with strangers who make promises, not about trusting people with magic.
differentiation_notes: Targets overall moral about evaluating offers from strangers - differs from reference which focuses on trusting strangers with promises
homogeneity_check: all choices are potential life lessons or morals from the story
specificity_check: all state general principles with similar abstraction level
length_check: A: 11 words, B: 8 words, C: 9 words, D: 10 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: distinct lessons: caution about motives vs trust in identity vs desperation acceptance vs magical trust
single_correct_check: only A captures the central caution message supported by story events
diversity_check: targets moral about evaluating stranger motives, uses 'what lesson' stem instead of 'central message' - distinct from reference

question: Which detail from the story best supports the message about being careful with people who seem too generous?
option_1: The magician promises to help Aladdin become a merchant but really wants the lamp
option_2: Aladdin's father worked as a tailor making clothes for people
option_3: The magician uses sweet-smelling perfumes and magical words to open the earth
option_4: Aladdin finds a lamp hanging from a tree in a beautiful garden
option_1_explanation: Correct! This detail directly supports the story's warning about generous strangers. The text shows the magician promised 'to help Aladdin learn to become a merchant and earn good money' but 'was not really Aladdin's uncle at all' and 'only cared about getting the magic lamp.' His false generosity to gain Aladdin's trust is the key detail that conveys the lesson about being cautious.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. Information about Aladdin's father's job helps establish that the family is poor, but does not relate to the lesson about being careful with overly generous strangers. This detail provides background, not the central message.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The magical opening of the earth is an exciting story event, but does not convey the lesson about trusting generous strangers. The important detail is the magician's false promises and deception, not his magical abilities.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Finding the lamp is part of the plot, but does not support the message about caution with strangers. The key detail is how the magician deceived Aladdin with false promises of help, not the description of where the lamp was located.
differentiation_notes: Targets identifying supporting detail for moral from paragraph 2 setup - differs from reference which asks for overall message
homogeneity_check: all choices are specific details or events from the story
specificity_check: all cite particular story elements with similar concrete detail
length_check: A: 13 words, B: 10 words, C: 11 words, D: 11 words - balanced within 10%

single_correct_check: only A identifies detail that directly conveys the caution message
diversity_check: targets paragraph 2 deception detail as evidence for moral, requires identifying which detail supports lesson - different from reference asking for lesson itself

question: How does the author use the magician's actions throughout the story to teach a lesson about trust?
option_1: By showing he lies about his identity, makes promises, then betrays Aladdin
option_2: By describing how he uses powerful magic spells and perfumes
option_3: By explaining that he traveled a very long distance to find the lamp
option_4: By revealing that he gives Aladdin a special ring for protection
option_1_explanation: Correct! The author builds the lesson through a pattern of the magician's deceptive actions. First, 'the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all.' Then he promises to 'help Aladdin learn to become a merchant and earn good money.' Finally, when Aladdin cannot give him the lamp immediately, 'He spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place' trapping him. This sequence of lying, promising, and betraying teaches readers to be cautious about trusting strangers.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. While the magician's magic makes the story exciting, describing his spells does not teach the lesson about trust. The lesson comes from showing how he deceives Aladdin with false promises, not from his magical abilities.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. His long journey shows his determination but does not teach about trust. The lesson is conveyed through his pattern of lying about being family, making promises to help Aladdin, then betraying him when he gets what he wants.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Giving Aladdin the ring might seem generous, but the text explains he needed Aladdin protected to get the lamp. The lesson about trust comes from showing his overall pattern of deception and betrayal, not from one seemingly helpful act.
differentiation_notes: Targets author's craft across multiple paragraphs building lesson through action sequence - differs from reference which asks for lesson statement

question: Based on the whole story, what message can readers learn about offers that seem too good to be true?
option_1: They often come from people who want something for themselves
option_2: They always involve magic and require special rings for safety
option_3: They usually require climbing mountains to reach hidden treasures
option_4: They happen most often when you meet long-lost family members
option_1_explanation: Correct! The magician's offer to make Aladdin rich seemed wonderful, but the text reveals 'He only cared about getting the magic lamp.' The story shows that when something seems too good to be true (instant wealth from a 'uncle' you never met), the person making the offer usually has selfish motives. This teaches readers to question why someone would make such generous promises.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. Magic and rings are specific story elements, not the life lesson. The message is broader - about being cautious when offers seem too generous. Many real situations involve people with selfish motives, even without magic.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Climbing mountains and hidden treasures are specific plot details, not the universal lesson. The message applies to any situation where someone makes promises that seem too good to be true, not just treasure hunts.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The 'long-lost family member' is part of this specific story's deception, but the broader lesson is about any offer that seems too generous. The text shows 'the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all,' teaching that false claims can be part of deception.
differentiation_notes: Targets universal application of lesson about suspicious generosity - differs from reference specific trust message

question: Why does the magician pretend to be Aladdin’s uncle?
option_1: So he can help Aladdin become a rich merchant.
option_2: Because he is truly part of Aladdin’s family.
option_3: To get Aladdin to bring him the magic lamp.
option_4: So he can take Aladdin for a long mountain walk.
option_1_explanation: You may have focused on the promise to help Aladdin become a merchant, but the story says he was “a powerful magician” who came “to search for a special magic lamp,” and later he says, “First, hand me the lamp.” This shows his real goal was the lamp, not making Aladdin rich. The correct answer is that he wanted Aladdin to bring him the magic lamp. Next time, check the character’s actions and repeated clues, not just their first promise.
option_2_explanation: You may have thought he was truly family because he hugged Aladdin and called him 'nephew,' but the text says, "the stranger was not really Aladdin’s uncle at all" and later, "He only cared about getting the magic lamp." This shows he pretended to be family to get Aladdin to bring him the lamp, which is the correct answer. Next time, reread to find the sentence that tells a character’s real reason, not just their first actions or words.
option_3_explanation: You successfully identified a character’s motive by noticing the magician pretended to be Aladdin’s uncle so Aladdin would bring him the lamp. The text supports this when it says he came “to search for a special magic lamp… [and] needed someone to help him,” and later he demands, “First, hand me the lamp.” Remember to ask yourself, “What does the character want?” and look for lines that state goals or demands when answering similar questions.
option_4_explanation: It looks like you focused on the long walk up the mountain, but the text says the magician came “to search for a special magic lamp,” told Aladdin “Bring that lamp back to me,” and “only cared about getting the magic lamp,” so his goal wasn’t the walk. The correct answer is that he took Aladdin to get him to bring the magic lamp. Next time, look for what the character wants most (the main goal) and make sure your answer matches that, not just one event.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
passage_text:
Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
    
    
        There once was a poor boy named Aladdin. His father worked as a tailor, making clothes for people. When his father died, Aladdin's mother had to work hard to earn money for food and shelter.One day, a stranger walked up to Aladdin on the street. "Tell me, young man," said the stranger. "Are you the son of the tailor who lived here?""Yes, I am," said Aladdin.The stranger threw his arms around Aladdin and hugged him tight. "My dear nephew!" he cried out. "Your father was my brother! Now I learn that he has died! What terrible news!"

---

Aladdin brought the man home to meet his mother. She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother. Even so, she welcomed the man into their home. When the stranger promised to help Aladdin learn to become a merchant and earn good money, she believed his words.But the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all. He was actually a powerful magician who had traveled from far away in North Africa. He had come all the way to Persia to search for a special magic lamp. People said this lamp had amazing powers that would make any person very rich. To find this lamp, the magician needed someone to help him. He wanted to find a person who would follow his directions without asking too many questions. He thought Aladdin was exactly the right person for this job.

---

The next morning, the magician came to Aladdin's house. "Come with me today," he said to the boy. "I want to introduce you to other merchants in the city." Then he led Aladdin away from town and out into the countryside.The magician took Aladdin up a very steep mountain path. They climbed higher and higher for a whole hour. Finally, they reached a spot where no flowers or plants could grow. The ground looked empty and bare."Go gather some dry sticks," the magician told Aladdin. "We will build a fire here. Then I will show you something truly amazing."Aladdin did exactly what the man asked him to do. The magician lit the fire with the sticks. Then he threw sweet-smelling perfumes into the flames and spoke magical words in a loud voice. Suddenly, the bright sky turned dark like night. Thunder crashed and rumbled all around them. The earth split open right at their feet. There in front of them lay a huge stone with a brass ring attached to it.

---

"Under this heavy stone lies a great treasure," said the magician. "It will make you richer than any king in the world. Lift the stone by pulling on the ring. Then go down the stairs. You will see many treasures as you walk, but you must not touch any of them. You will come to a beautiful garden. In that garden, you will see a lamp hanging from a tree. Bring that lamp back to me. Once you have the lamp, you may take any treasures you want."Aladdin felt amazed by what he heard. He could hardly believe what the magician was asking him to do. But he agreed to help."Take this special ring," said the magician. "It will keep you safe from any harm." Aladdin took the ring and put it on his finger. Then he pulled the heavy stone up by its brass ring and went down into the dark cave below.Aladdin found the lamp and filled his bag with beautiful gems. But all those gems made his bag very heavy. When he climbed back to the top of the stairs, he could not pull himself out of the cave opening."Give me your hand, Uncle," Aladdin called out. "Help me climb out!""First, hand me the lamp," the magician answered back.The lamp was buried deep in Aladdin's heavy bag. "I cannot reach it right now," Aladdin said.The magician grew very angry. He only cared about getting the magic lamp. When Aladdin said he would give it to him after climbing out, the impatient magician could not wait any longer. He spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place. Poor Aladdin was trapped in the dark cave below.
question: Why does the author include the detail that the magician comes from 'far away in North Africa' to find the lamp?
option_1: To show how desperately he wants the lamp and will go to great lengths to get it
option_2: To explain why he does not know Aladdin's family well
option_3: To describe the long journey that made him very tired
option_4: To teach readers about different countries and their customs
option_1_explanation: Correct! The text explains the magician 'had traveled from far away in North Africa' and 'had come all the way to Persia to search for a special magic lamp.' This detail emphasizes the magician's obsessive desire for the lamp - he traveled enormous distances, which reveals his true priority. This helps convey the message that he never cared about Aladdin, only about getting the lamp. His willingness to travel so far and deceive people shows his selfish determination.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. While coming from far away could explain not knowing the family, this is not why the author includes this detail. The magician lied about being the brother anyway. The detail emphasizes his extreme determination to get the lamp, which supports the lesson about his selfish motives.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The text does not describe the magician as tired. In fact, he energetically climbs a mountain with Aladdin. The detail about his distant origin shows his obsessive pursuit of the lamp and supports the message about his deception, not about being tired.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. This is a folk tale, not an informational text about countries. The author mentions North Africa to emphasize the extreme lengths the magician will go to get what he wants, which supports the story's lesson about being cautious with self-serving strangers.
differentiation_notes: Targets author's purpose for paragraph 2 geographic detail to support theme - differs from reference which asks for overall message
homogeneity_check: all choices are potential reasons the author included the geographic detail
specificity_check: all explain author's purpose with similar analytical reasoning
length_check: A: 14 words, B: 9 words, C: 9 words, D: 9 words - within 35% range, acceptable
semantic_distance_check: distinct purposes: showing obsession vs explaining unfamiliarity vs describing fatigue vs teaching geography
single_correct_check: only A explains how detail supports story's message about magician's selfish priorities
diversity_check: targets author's craft reason for paragraph 2 detail supporting theme, requires analyzing why specific information included - different from reference message question

question: What is the magician's real reason for pretending to be part of Aladdin's family?
option_1: To make Aladdin trust him so the boy will help retrieve the magic lamp
option_2: To become close friends with Aladdin and teach him about magic
option_3: To find out if Aladdin's father left behind any valuable treasures
option_4: To move to Persia and start a new life with a loving family
option_1_explanation: Correct! The text clearly explains his deception and motive: 'the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all. He was actually a powerful magician' who 'needed someone to help him' find the lamp. He 'wanted to find a person who would follow his directions without asking too many questions.' By pretending to be family, he gained trust so Aladdin would obey him and enter the dangerous cave to get the lamp.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. The magician never wanted friendship or to teach Aladdin. The text says 'He only cared about getting the magic lamp.' Everything he did was to trick Aladdin into helping him get the lamp, not to build a genuine relationship.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The text never suggests Aladdin's father had treasures. In fact, the story establishes the family was poor - the father was 'a tailor' and the mother 'had to work hard to earn money.' The magician wanted the magic lamp in the cave, not anything from Aladdin's father.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The magician 'had traveled from far away in North Africa' specifically to 'search for a special magic lamp,' not to find a family. He lied about being family as a trick to manipulate Aladdin, and the text shows 'He only cared about getting the magic lamp.'
differentiation_notes: Targets magician's strategic deception motive from paragraph 2 - differs from reference which asks why he pretends generally
homogeneity_check: all choices are potential motivations for the deception
specificity_check: all provide specific goals with similar explanatory depth

question: How does the magician's behavior at the end of the story reveal his true character and purpose?
option_1: He abandons Aladdin when he cannot get the lamp immediately, showing he only cared about the treasure
option_2: He gives detailed instructions about not touching treasures, showing he wants to keep Aladdin safe
option_3: He uses magic to open the earth, showing he has powerful abilities from studying for years
option_4: He climbs the steep mountain with Aladdin, showing he is willing to work hard for his goals
option_1_explanation: Correct! The text shows his true nature in the final paragraph: 'The magician grew very angry. He only cared about getting the magic lamp.' When Aladdin needed help climbing out but could not hand over the lamp right away, the 'impatient magician could not wait any longer. He spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place. Poor Aladdin was trapped in the dark cave below.' His willingness to trap a child reveals he never intended to help Aladdin - he only wanted the lamp for himself.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. His instructions were not about safety - he told Aladdin not to touch treasures because 'To find this lamp, the magician needed someone to help him' and he wanted Aladdin focused on getting the lamp. His behavior at the end, trapping Aladdin, proves he did not care about the boy's safety.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. While his magic demonstrates his power, this does not reveal his true character. His character is revealed when he traps Aladdin rather than helping him. The text states 'He only cared about getting the magic lamp,' showing his selfish purpose, not just his abilities.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Climbing the mountain was necessary to reach the lamp's location, not evidence of good character. His true character is revealed at the end when he 'spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place,' trapping Aladdin instead of helping him out of the cave.

question: Based on evidence throughout the story, what was the magician's plan from the very beginning?
option_1: To deceive Aladdin into trusting him, then use the boy to retrieve the lamp for himself
option_2: To adopt Aladdin as his nephew and share the lamp's magical powers together
option_3: To help Aladdin's poor family by finding treasures they could sell for money
option_4: To teach Aladdin the merchant trade by showing him valuable items in the cave
option_1_explanation: Correct! He thought Aladdin was exactly the right person for this job.' He lied about being family, promised to help Aladdin become a merchant, led him to the cave, and finally 'He only cared about getting the magic lamp' - abandoning Aladdin when he could not get it immediately. Every action was part of his plan to use Aladdin.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. The magician never intended to share anything. The text explicitly states he 'was not really Aladdin's uncle at all' and at the end, 'He only cared about getting the magic lamp.' His plan was always to trick Aladdin into getting the lamp, then take it for himself.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. His promise to help the family was a lie. The text shows he 'had come all the way to Persia to search for a special magic lamp' for himself. He told the mother he would help 'and she believed his words,' but this was deception to gain access to Aladdin.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part II
passage_text:
Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part II
    
    
        Aladdin was stuck in the dark cave. "Uncle!" he called out. "Please help me!" But no one answered. The magician had gone back to North Africa. He only wanted the magic lamp. Since Aladdin would not help him get it, he did not care about Aladdin anymore.For three whole days, Aladdin stayed in the black cave. First, he yelled for help. Then, he cried. Finally, he put his hands together to pray. When he did this, he rubbed the ring on his finger. The magician had put this ring there. Suddenly, a genie appeared in front of him."What do you wish for?" asked the genie of the ring.Aladdin was scared, but he said, "Take me out of this cave!" In a flash, Aladdin found himself outside again. He ran home fast to tell his mother everything that had happened. He showed her the beautiful gems from the cave. His mother thought they were just pretty stones. Then, he showed her the old lamp.

---

"This lamp is so dirty," said Aladdin's mother. "Let me clean it. Then maybe I can sell it to buy us some food." She took a cloth and started rubbing the lamp. All at once, a huge genie appeared! This genie was much bigger than the first one."What is your wish?" the genie thundered in a loud voice.Aladdin's mother was so frightened she almost fell down. Aladdin quickly said, "We are very hungry! Please bring us something to eat!" The genie disappeared and came back with twelve gold plates full of delicious food. Aladdin and his mother ate until they were full. Later, they sold the silver plates and bought more food with the money.

---

One day, Aladdin told his mother, "I want to marry the Sultan's daughter." His mother laughed. "Have you lost your mind?" she said. "Your father was just a poor tailor!" But Aladdin said, "Remember those shiny gems from the cave? Take them as a gift to the Sultan."Aladdin's mother went to see the Sultan. "My lord," she said, "my son Aladdin wants to marry your daughter." The Sultan laughed loudly. "Your son and my daughter? That's silly!" But when Aladdin's mother opened her cloth and showed the gems, the Sultan stopped laughing. He looked closely at the sparkling stones."These are amazing!" the Sultan thought. "I have never seen such beautiful gems!" Then the Sultan said, "Your son may marry my daughter, but only if he sends me forty servants. Each servant must carry a bowl full of gems like these."

---

When Aladdin heard this, he rubbed his magic lamp. The genie appeared right away. Aladdin told the genie what the Sultan wanted. Almost instantly, the genie brought forty servants. Each servant carried a large golden bowl. Half the bowls were filled with pearls and diamonds. The other bowls were filled with rubies and emeralds.The Sultan was amazed by all the treasure. He agreed that Aladdin could marry his daughter. Aladdin was so happy! He rubbed the lamp again. The genie appeared and prepared a wedding fit for a prince. The servants brought Aladdin fine clothes and sweet perfumes. They gave him a beautiful horse to ride. They even built him a palace right next to the Sultan's palace. They rolled out a thick red carpet from the Sultan's home to Aladdin's new palace. When the Sultan saw the magnificent palace, he knew Aladdin was perfect for his daughter. They celebrated with a wonderful feast, music, and dancing that lasted all day and all night.
question: How does Aladdin most likely feel when he sees the forty servants with bowls of gems?
option_1: happy
option_2: angry
option_3: worried
option_4: scared
option_1_explanation: You successfully identified key details to figure out how Aladdin felt by noticing the sentence that names his emotion. The text supports this when it says, “Aladdin was so happy!” Remember to look for feeling words (like happy, scared, excited) or what a character does right after something happens to answer emotion questions.
option_2_explanation: You may have focused on the scary cave part and thought Aladdin felt angry, but look at the line, “He agreed that Aladdin could marry his daughter. Aladdin was so happy!”—this clearly shows the opposite feeling. The correct answer is happy because the Sultan said yes and the story states it directly. Next time, reread the exact sentence about feelings and choose the word the text uses.
option_3_explanation: You may have focused on an earlier part when Aladdin was scared in the cave, which makes “worried” sound right. But in the part the question points to, the text says, “Aladdin was so happy!” after the Sultan agrees and the genie prepares the wedding, so the correct answer is happy. Next time, reread the exact part the question is about and look for feeling words the author uses.
option_4_explanation: You may have focused on the earlier part when “Aladdin was scared” in the cave, but look at the ending: after the Sultan agreed, the text says, “Aladdin was so happy!” So “scared” describes an earlier moment, while “happy” matches how he felt at the end. Next time, reread the part of the story that the question is asking about (beginning, middle, or end) and look for clue words that show the character’s feeling.

Aladdin quickly said, "We are very hungry! Please bring us something to eat!" The genie disappeared and came back with twelve gold plates full of delicious food. Aladdin and his mother ate until they were full. Later, they sold the silver plates and bought more food with the money.

---

One day, Aladdin told his mother, "I want to marry the Sultan's daughter." His mother laughed. "Have you lost your mind?" she said. "Your father was just a poor tailor!" But Aladdin said, "Remember those shiny gems from the cave? Take them as a gift to the Sultan."Aladdin's mother went to see the Sultan. "My lord," she said, "my son Aladdin wants to marry your daughter." The Sultan laughed loudly. "Your son and my daughter? That's silly!" But when Aladdin's mother opened her cloth and showed the gems, the Sultan stopped laughing. He looked closely at the sparkling stones."These are amazing!" the Sultan thought. "I have never seen such beautiful gems!" Then the Sultan said, "Your son may marry my daughter, but only if he sends me forty servants. Each servant must carry a bowl full of gems like these."

---

When Aladdin heard this, he rubbed his magic lamp. The genie appeared right away. Aladdin told the genie what the Sultan wanted. Almost instantly, the genie brought forty servants. Each servant carried a large golden bowl. Half the bowls were filled with pearls and diamonds. The other bowls were filled with rubies and emeralds.The Sultan was amazed by all the treasure. He agreed that Aladdin could marry his daughter. Aladdin was so happy! He rubbed the lamp again. The genie appeared and prepared a wedding fit for a prince. The servants brought Aladdin fine clothes and sweet perfumes. They gave him a beautiful horse to ride. They even built him a palace right next to the Sultan's palace. They rolled out a thick red carpet from the Sultan's home to Aladdin's new palace. When the Sultan saw the magnificent palace, he knew Aladdin was perfect for his daughter. They celebrated with a wonderful feast, music, and dancing that lasted all day and all night.
question: Based on the story, what does Aladdin do when his mother is scared by the lamp's genie?
option_1: He runs away from the genie
option_2: He asks the genie for food
option_3: He hides behind his mother
option_4: He rubs the lamp again
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. The text says Aladdin 'quickly said' something to the genie, showing he stayed and took action rather than running away. Review what Aladdin does when his mother is frightened.
option_2_explanation: Correct! The passage states that when 'Aladdin's mother was so frightened she almost fell down,' Aladdin quickly responded by saying 'We are very hungry! Please bring us something to eat!' This shows he stayed calm and made a request to help both of them. This action reveals Aladdin's courage and quick thinking.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The story shows Aladdin taking charge of the situation by speaking to the genie, not hiding. Look for what Aladdin says when the genie appears.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. His mother was already rubbing the lamp when the genie appeared. Aladdin spoke to the genie instead of touching the lamp. Find the part where Aladdin responds to the genie's question.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part II

Earlier with the ring genie, the text also notes 'Aladdin was scared, but he said' his wish, showing courage despite fear.

question: What helps Aladdin the most in this story?
option_1: The magic ring and lamp.
option_2: The gems from the cave.
option_3: His mother’s visit to the Sultan.
option_4: The magician’s help.
option_1_explanation: You successfully identified key details by noticing the two magical objects that helped Aladdin: the ring and the lamp. The text supports this with “he rubbed the ring on his finger… a genie appeared” and “she… started rubbing the lamp. All at once, a huge genie appeared!” Remember to scan for cause-and-effect moments—when a character uses something and something big happens—to answer similar “which/what helped” questions.
option_2_explanation: You may have focused on the shiny treasure, but the text says the gems were “just pretty stones” and used as gifts—they never cause magic. When Aladdin rubs the ring “a genie appeared,” and when his mother rubs the lamp “a huge genie appeared,” so the magic items are the ring and the lamp, not the gems. Strategy: Reread for cause-and-effect clues (like “when he rubbed…, a genie appeared”) to choose the items that actually make things happen.
option_3_explanation: It looks like you focused on one event (his mother’s visit), but the text shows the ring and lamp are what make everything happen: the ring genie gets Aladdin out of the cave, and the lamp genie brings food, forty servants with bowls of gems, and even builds a palace—after this, the Sultan agrees. So the correct answer is the magic ring and lamp because they help Aladdin again and again, not just once. Strategy: ask yourself, “What helps the main character throughout the whole story, not just in one scene?”
option_4_explanation: You may have mixed up who helped Aladdin; the text says, “The magician had gone back to North Africa… he did not care about Aladdin anymore,” so he gave no help. Instead, rubbing the ring and later the lamp made genies appear who freed him and brought food, servants, and a palace—so the correct answer is the magic ring and lamp. Tip: Reread and underline the sentences that show who actually helps before choosing your answer.

question: What lesson does the story teach about being resourceful?
option_1: Having magical objects can solve any problem
option_2: Using what you have wisely leads to success
option_3: Asking others for help is always the best choice
option_4: Finding treasure makes all your dreams come true
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. While magic helps Aladdin, the story emphasizes how he uses the objects thoughtfully, not just that he possesses them. The central message is deeper than simply having magic.
option_2_explanation: Correct! Throughout the story, Aladdin succeeds by using the resources he has wisely. He cleverly uses the ring genie to escape, the lamp genie to get food and wealth, and the gems to impress the Sultan. Each time, he thinks about what he needs and uses his magical items purposefully. The story shows that being clever with what you have leads to good outcomes, which is conveyed through Aladdin's successful use of the ring, lamp, and gems.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The story actually shows the opposite - the magician abandons Aladdin, and Aladdin must rely on his own resourcefulness with the magical objects to succeed.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The treasure alone doesn't bring success - Aladdin must think strategically about how to use it. The story emphasizes smart actions, not just luck.
differentiation_notes: Targets overall story theme about resourcefulness - differs from reference which asks what helps Aladdin most (specific objects vs. broader lesson)

specificity_check: all state general principles about success

single_correct_check: only B captures the central message about resourceful use of what you have

"This lamp is so dirty," said Aladdin's mother. "Let me clean it. Then maybe I can sell it to buy us some food." She took a cloth and started rubbing the lamp. All at once, a huge genie appeared! This genie was much bigger than the first one."What is your wish?" the genie thundered in a loud voice.Aladdin's mother was so frightened she almost fell down. Aladdin quickly said, "We are very hungry! Please bring us something to eat!" The genie disappeared and came back with twelve gold plates full of delicious food. Aladdin and his mother ate until they were full. Later, they sold the silver plates and bought more food with the money.

---

One day, Aladdin told his mother, "I want to marry the Sultan's daughter." His mother laughed. "Have you lost your mind?" she said. "Your father was just a poor tailor!" But Aladdin said, "Remember those shiny gems from the cave? Take them as a gift to the Sultan."Aladdin's mother went to see the Sultan. "My lord," she said, "my son Aladdin wants to marry your daughter." The Sultan laughed loudly. "Your son and my daughter? That's silly!" But when Aladdin's mother opened her cloth and showed the gems, the Sultan stopped laughing. He looked closely at the sparkling stones."These are amazing!" the Sultan thought. "I have never seen such beautiful gems!" Then the Sultan said, "Your son may marry my daughter, but only if he sends me forty servants. Each servant must carry a bowl full of gems like these."

---

When Aladdin heard this, he rubbed his magic lamp. The genie appeared right away. Aladdin told the genie what the Sultan wanted. Almost instantly, the genie brought forty servants. Each servant carried a large golden bowl. Half the bowls were filled with pearls and diamonds. The other bowls were filled with rubies and emeralds.The Sultan was amazed by all the treasure. He agreed that Aladdin could marry his daughter. Aladdin was so happy! He rubbed the lamp again. The genie appeared and prepared a wedding fit for a prince. The servants brought Aladdin fine clothes and sweet perfumes. They gave him a beautiful horse to ride. They even built him a palace right next to the Sultan's palace. They rolled out a thick red carpet from the Sultan's home to Aladdin's new palace. When the Sultan saw the magnificent palace, he knew Aladdin was perfect for his daughter. They celebrated with a wonderful feast, music, and dancing that lasted all day and all night.
question: Based on the story, what central message is shown through Aladdin's journey from the cave to the palace?
option_1: Courage and quick thinking can change your life
option_2: Family members should always trust each other
option_3: Magical genies are the answer to every wish
option_4: Rich people are happier than poor people
option_1_explanation: Correct! The story demonstrates this message through key details: Aladdin shows courage by speaking to scary genies when others are frightened, and quick thinking by knowing what to ask for at each moment. He escapes the cave by accidentally activating the ring, cleverly gets food when hungry, and strategically fulfills the Sultan's challenge. These examples of bravery and smart decisions transform him from a poor tailor's son trapped in a cave to a prince in a palace, conveying the central message that courage and cleverness lead to success.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. The story actually shows distrust - the magician pretends to be Aladdin's uncle but betrays him. Family trust is not the main lesson being taught.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. While genies help, the story focuses on how Aladdin uses them wisely, not that magic solves everything automatically. The central message is about personal qualities, not magic.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The story shows Aladdin becoming successful, but the central message is about how his actions lead to happiness, not that wealth itself creates happiness.
differentiation_notes: Targets the arc from cave to palace analyzing courage/thinking - differs from reference which asks about specific helpful elements

specificity_check: all state broad thematic conclusions
length_check: A:7 words, B:6 words, C:7 words, D:6 words - balanced within 15%
semantic_distance_check: distinct themes - courage/thinking, trust, magic, wealth are different moral lessons
single_correct_check: only A is supported by the progression of events showing courage and cleverness
diversity_check: targets overall character arc cave-to-palace - different from reference about helpful objects and variant 1 about resourcefulness, focuses on personal qualities

question: What does the story reveal about the importance of persistence through Aladdin's actions?
option_1: Giving up when things are hard keeps you safe
option_2: Waiting for others to help is the smartest plan
option_3: Continuing to try different solutions brings results
option_4: Luck is more important than making an effort
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Aladdin doesn't give up in the cave - he keeps trying different approaches (yelling, crying, praying) until something works. The story teaches the opposite of giving up.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. When the magician abandons him, Aladdin doesn't wait passively. He takes action himself by praying and accidentally activating the ring. Review what Aladdin does in the cave.
option_3_explanation: Correct! The story conveys this message through Aladdin's persistence in the cave: 'First, he yelled for help. Then, he cried. Finally, he put his hands together to pray.' Each attempt represents a different approach, and his continued efforts eventually lead to rubbing the ring and escaping. Later, he persists by sending his mother to the Sultan, then meeting the challenge with forty servants. Key details show that not giving up and trying various solutions ultimately brings success.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. While Aladdin accidentally rubs the ring, the story emphasizes his continuous efforts and smart choices, not random luck. His success comes from persistent action.
differentiation_notes: Targets Aladdin's persistence in trying multiple approaches - differs from reference about what helps most and focuses on behavioral pattern

question: Which detail best shows the moral that cleverness is more valuable than riches?
option_1: The Sultan owns many treasures but still wants more gems
option_2: Aladdin knows when to use the ring and when to use the lamp
option_3: The magician travels far to find the magical lamp
option_4: Aladdin's mother thinks the gems are just pretty stones
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. This detail shows the Sultan's desire for wealth, but doesn't demonstrate that cleverness is more valuable. Look for examples of smart thinking leading to success.
option_2_explanation: Correct! This detail conveys the moral about cleverness being valuable. The text shows Aladdin making strategic decisions: using the ring genie to escape the cave, using the lamp genie to get food when hungry, and later using it again to fulfill the Sultan's challenge and prepare for the wedding. His intelligent choices about when and how to use his magical resources demonstrate that thinking wisely is more important than simply having valuable objects. The story shows his cleverness transforms simple magic into life-changing success.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The magician's journey shows determination but not the moral about cleverness versus riches. Focus on how Aladdin uses smart thinking throughout the story.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. His mother not recognizing the gems' value shows her lack of knowledge about jewels, but doesn't illustrate the cleverness-over-riches moral. Find details about Aladdin's smart decisions.
differentiation_notes: Targets the cleverness vs. riches theme through Aladdin's strategic choices - differs from reference about what helps most (objects vs. wisdom in using them)

question: Why did the author write this story about Aladdin?
option_1: to explain how genies grant wishes to people who find them
option_2: to show how kindness and cleverness can lead to happiness
option_3: to teach people how to find magic lamps and genies
option_4: to describe what life was like long ago
option_1_explanation: You may have focused on the exciting detail of genies and wishes, but the text does not explain how genies work. It shows Aladdin being kind and clever: he gives the Sultan gems and uses the lamp to send “forty servants… each carrying a bowl full of gems,” so “the Sultan agreed that Aladdin could marry his daughter.” That means the main idea is that kindness and cleverness can lead to happiness. Next time, check what the whole story is mostly about, not just one exciting detail.
option_2_explanation: You successfully identified the story’s message by noticing how Aladdin’s kindness and clever problem-solving lead to a happy ending. The text supports this when he “quickly said, ‘We are very hungry! Please bring us something to eat!’” and later uses the lamp to meet the Sultan’s challenge, after which “Aladdin was so happy!” and “They celebrated… all day and all night.” Remember to look at what the main character does to solve problems and how the story ends to figure out the theme in similar passages.
option_3_explanation: You may have thought the story teaches how to find magic lamps, but the text never gives steps; Aladdin meets the genies by accident when he rubs a ring while praying and when his mother cleans a dirty lamp. Instead, the story shows that kind, smart choices lead to good things—he says, “Please bring us something to eat,” meets the Sultan’s challenge with help, and it ends with a happy wedding and feast. Strategy: For main idea questions, ask if the passage is a how-to or a lesson, and check how the story ends.
option_4_explanation: You may have focused on the “long ago” setting, but the text doesn’t describe real life in the past—there are magical genies and no facts about daily life. Notice how Aladdin kindly asks for food for his mother and cleverly solves the Sultan’s demand with the genie’s help, which leads to a wedding and a palace; this shows the lesson that kindness and cleverness can lead to happiness. Next time, ask yourself: Is the author giving facts, or telling a story to teach a lesson?
