article_title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
passage_text:
Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
    
    
        Alice had just drunk from a strange little bottle. The liquid tasted very odd and made her feel funny."What a strange feeling!" said Alice. She was getting smaller and smaller. Soon, she was only ten inches tall. Now she was the perfect size to go through the tiny door to the beautiful garden. But when Alice got to the door, she realized something terrible. She had forgotten the little golden key on the table!Alice went back to get the key, but now she had a big problem. She was too short to reach the table! Alice sat down and started to cry. Then she noticed a small glass box under the table. Inside the box was a tiny cake with the words 'EAT ME' written on top with small pieces of fruit.

---

"I will eat this cake," Alice said with excitement. As soon as she took a bite, something amazing happened."How strange!" cried Alice. "Now I am growing bigger and bigger! I can barely see my feet!" Alice grew so tall that her head hit the ceiling of the hall. She was now nine feet tall! She quickly grabbed the golden key and ran to the garden door. But now she had the opposite problem. She was much too big to fit through the doorway. All she could do was look into the garden with one eye.Alice felt so sad that she sat down and cried again. She cried so many tears that they made a big pool of water around her. While she was crying, Alice heard footsteps. It was the White Rabbit coming back! He looked very fancy with white gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other hand.

---

The White Rabbit was talking to himself. "Oh no! The Duchess will be so angry if I am late!" When Alice tried to talk to him, the Rabbit got scared. He dropped his gloves and fan and ran away quickly into the dark."Everything is so weird today!" said Alice. As she spoke, Alice noticed she was getting smaller again. Suddenly, splash! She fell into the pool of water she had made with her own tears. Poor Alice had to swim around in her own tear pool!"I wish I had not cried so much!" Alice said as she swam around looking for a way out. Alice was not the type of person to sit still and do nothing. After she got out of the pool, she decided to explore more of Wonderland.

---

Soon Alice found a large blue Caterpillar sitting on top of a mushroom. The Caterpillar was smoking a long pipe. Alice stood on her toes and looked over the edge of the mushroom. The Caterpillar and Alice stared at each other for a long time without saying anything.Finally, the Caterpillar took the pipe out of his mouth and asked, "Who are you?" Alice felt confused. "I do not really know, sir. I knew who I was this morning, but I have changed so many times today." The Caterpillar did not seem to understand Alice's problem with changing sizes.Before the Caterpillar crawled away, he told Alice something important. "One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter." Alice broke off a piece from each side of the mushroom. She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size.
question: Alice and the White Rabbit both react in the same way when they have problems. How do they react?
option_1: worriedly
option_2: angrily
option_3: silently
option_4: bravely
option_1_explanation: You successfully used context clues to figure out word meaning by noticing the Rabbit’s feelings and actions. The text says, “Oh no! The Duchess will be so angry if I am late!” and he “dropped his gloves and fan and ran away,” which shows he was acting worriedly. Remember to look at what a character says and does near the word to choose the best meaning next time.
option_2_explanation: You may have focused on the word “angry,” but in “Oh no! The Duchess will be so angry if I am late!” the anger belongs to the Duchess, not the Rabbit. The Rabbit says “Oh no!,” gets scared, drops his gloves and fan, and runs away—these are signs he is worried, so “worriedly” is correct. Next time, check which character the feeling belongs to and use action clues to match the emotion.
option_3_explanation: You may have chosen “silently” because another part says Alice and the Caterpillar stared without speaking, but here “The White Rabbit was talking to himself” and says, “Oh no! The Duchess will be so angry if I am late!”, so he isn’t silent. Those words show he feels nervous, so “worriedly” is the correct answer. Next time, reread the exact lines about the character and use clue words in the dialogue (like “Oh no!”) to match the feeling.
option_4_explanation: You may have focused on the Rabbit moving quickly and thought that meant he was acting bravely, but look at “Oh no! The Duchess will be so angry if I am late!” and “he got scared and ran away,” which show he is worried, not brave. The correct answer is worriedly because his words and actions show worry. Next time, reread the sentences around the clue and pick the word that matches the feelings shown in the text.

question: What does Alice do after she realizes she cannot solve a problem right away?
option_1: She gives up and stops trying.
option_2: She asks someone else for help.
option_3: She cries about her situation.
option_4: She makes a careful plan.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Alice does not give up. The text shows she continues trying different things throughout her adventure, like eating the cake and mushroom pieces.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. While Alice does encounter the White Rabbit and Caterpillar, she does not ask them for help solving her size problems. She tries to solve things on her own.
option_3_explanation: Correct. The text shows this pattern twice: 'Alice sat down and started to cry' when she couldn't reach the key, and 'She felt so sad that she sat down and cried again' when she was too big for the door. This demonstrates Alice's emotional reaction when facing problems.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Alice does not stop to make careful plans. Instead, she acts quickly and emotionally, trying things like eating the cake immediately and crying when upset.
differentiation_notes: Targets Alice's repeated emotional response pattern across multiple paragraphs, focusing on her actions rather than asking about both characters' shared reaction style as reference does.

specificity_check: All describe general action patterns

diversity_check: Focuses on Alice's individual action pattern across story sections vs. reference comparing two characters' shared traits

article_title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
passage_text:
Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
    
    
        Alice had just drunk from a strange little bottle. The liquid tasted very odd and made her feel funny."What a strange feeling!" said Alice. She was getting smaller and smaller. Soon, she was only ten inches tall. Now she was the perfect size to go through the tiny door to the beautiful garden. But when Alice got to the door, she realized something terrible. She had forgotten the little golden key on the table!Alice went back to get the key, but now she had a big problem. She was too short to reach the table! Alice sat down and started to cry. Then she noticed a small glass box under the table. Inside the box was a tiny cake with the words 'EAT ME' written on top with small pieces of fruit.

---

"I will eat this cake," Alice said with excitement. As soon as she took a bite, something amazing happened."How strange!" cried Alice. "Now I am growing bigger and bigger! I can barely see my feet!" Alice grew so tall that her head hit the ceiling of the hall. She was now nine feet tall! She quickly grabbed the golden key and ran to the garden door. But now she had the opposite problem. She was much too big to fit through the doorway. All she could do was look into the garden with one eye.Alice felt so sad that she sat down and cried again. She cried so many tears that they made a big pool of water around her. While she was crying, Alice heard footsteps. It was the White Rabbit coming back! He looked very fancy with white gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other hand.

---

The White Rabbit was talking to himself. "Oh no! The Duchess will be so angry if I am late!" When Alice tried to talk to him, the Rabbit got scared. He dropped his gloves and fan and ran away quickly into the dark."Everything is so weird today!" said Alice. As she spoke, Alice noticed she was getting smaller again. Suddenly, splash! She fell into the pool of water she had made with her own tears. Poor Alice had to swim around in her own tear pool!"I wish I had not cried so much!" Alice said as she swam around looking for a way out. Alice was not the type of person to sit still and do nothing. After she got out of the pool, she decided to explore more of Wonderland.

---

Soon Alice found a large blue Caterpillar sitting on top of a mushroom. The Caterpillar was smoking a long pipe. Alice stood on her toes and looked over the edge of the mushroom. The Caterpillar and Alice stared at each other for a long time without saying anything.Finally, the Caterpillar took the pipe out of his mouth and asked, "Who are you?" Alice felt confused. "I do not really know, sir. I knew who I was this morning, but I have changed so many times today." The Caterpillar did not seem to understand Alice's problem with changing sizes.Before the Caterpillar crawled away, he told Alice something important. "One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter." Alice broke off a piece from each side of the mushroom. She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size.
question: Based on the Caterpillar's reaction to Alice, what can readers tell about his personality?
option_1: He is patient and understanding.
option_2: He is confused and curious.
option_3: He is unhelpful and uninterested.
option_4: He is friendly and talkative.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. The Caterpillar is not patient or understanding. He 'did not seem to understand Alice's problem with changing sizes' and stares at her for a long time without speaking, showing little patience.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. While the Caterpillar asks 'Who are you?' he does not show curiosity about Alice's situation. He does not ask follow-up questions or try to understand her problem.
option_3_explanation: Correct. The text shows the Caterpillar 'did not seem to understand Alice's problem' and they 'stared at each other for a long time without saying anything.' He only gives brief advice before crawling away, demonstrating disinterest in helping Alice with her confusion.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The Caterpillar is not friendly or talkative. He sits in silence, asks only one question, and crawls away after giving brief advice without engaging in conversation.
differentiation_notes: Analyzes the Caterpillar's character traits from paragraph 4, requiring inference from his minimal dialogue and actions, different from reference which examines shared reactions between Alice and White Rabbit.
homogeneity_check: All choices are personality trait pairs
specificity_check: All use two adjectives describing character
length_check: A:5 words, B:4 words, C:4 words, D:4 words - balanced within 20%
semantic_distance_check: Each pair represents distinct personality types with clear differences
single_correct_check: Only C matches the Caterpillar's actual behavior described in text
diversity_check: Targets Caterpillar's traits in final section vs. reference examining Alice and Rabbit's shared emotional responses

question: Which character trait does Alice show when she decides to explore Wonderland after getting out of the pool?
option_1: laziness
option_2: determination
option_3: confusion
option_4: fear
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Alice is not lazy. The text explicitly states 'Alice was not the type of person to sit still and do nothing,' which is the opposite of laziness.
option_2_explanation: Correct. After swimming in the tear pool, Alice 'was not the type of person to sit still and do nothing' and 'decided to explore more of Wonderland.' This shows her determination to keep going despite difficulties.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. While Alice does feel confused earlier, the question asks about her trait when deciding to explore. At this moment, she shows determination by actively choosing to continue her adventure.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Alice does not show fear when deciding to explore. If she were afraid, she would hide or try to escape, not actively explore more of Wonderland.
differentiation_notes: Focuses on Alice's proactive decision-making in paragraph 3 after the pool incident, examining her motivational traits rather than emotional reactions like the reference question.
homogeneity_check: All choices are single-word character traits
specificity_check: All are abstract personality characteristics
length_check: A:1 word, B:1 word, C:1 word, D:1 word - perfectly balanced
semantic_distance_check: Each trait is semantically distinct with no overlapping meanings
single_correct_check: Only B is supported by the text's description of Alice's active choice
diversity_check: Examines Alice's motivational trait in paragraph 3 vs. reference comparing emotional reactions of two characters

question: How does the White Rabbit's behavior when he sees Alice differ from when readers first met him?
option_1: He is calm instead of worried.
option_2: He is scared instead of fancy.
option_3: He is helpful instead of rushed.
option_4: He is quiet instead of talkative.

option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The White Rabbit does not help Alice at all. He runs away quickly when she tries to talk to him, and he remains rushed, worried about being late.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The White Rabbit is not quiet. He is 'talking to himself' about the Duchess being angry, showing he continues to speak.
differentiation_notes: Compares White Rabbit's behavior across two story sections (his fancy return vs. his frightened reaction), analyzing character change rather than shared traits between characters.

question: How does Alice get back to her normal size at the end of the passage?
option_1: She uses the White Rabbit’s fan and gloves.
option_2: She drinks from the bottle again.
option_3: She eats the cake.
option_4: She eats the mushroom.
option_1_explanation: You may be remembering another part of the story, but in this passage Alice does not use the White Rabbit’s fan and gloves—the Rabbit drops them and runs away. The text says, “One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller… She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size,” so the correct answer is that she eats the mushroom. Next time, reread the part where the character solves the problem and make sure your answer matches the exact words in the passage.
option_2_explanation: You may have focused on an earlier detail (the bottle), but in this part she does not drink again. The text says, “One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller… Alice broke off a piece… She ate tiny bites,” showing she eats the mushroom to change size. Next time, reread the sentences around the question’s part of the story to be sure your answer matches that moment.
option_3_explanation: You may have focused on the earlier part when Alice eats the cake and grows very tall, but look at the end: “One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller… She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size,” which shows she eats the mushroom. So the correct answer is: She eats the mushroom. Next time, reread the lines around the part the question is asking about to be sure your answer matches that moment in the story.
option_4_explanation: You successfully identified key details by noticing how Alice fixes her size. The text supports this when it says, “One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter… She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size,” showing she eats the mushroom. Next time, when a question asks what a character does, reread the part right after they get advice and look for action words to find the exact detail.

question: What important detail does the author include in paragraph 1 to show why Alice's size causes a new problem?
option_1: She forgets where she put the key.
option_2: She cannot reach the table anymore.
option_3: She drinks too much from the bottle.
option_4: She loses the cake under the table.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Alice does not forget where the key is. The text clearly states 'She had forgotten the little golden key on the table' but she knows its location - on the table. The problem is reaching it, not remembering where it is.
option_2_explanation: Correct. The text states 'She was too short to reach the table!' This detail directly shows how her smaller size creates the problem of not being able to get the key she needs, which is a key detail in understanding the sequence of events.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The text does not say Alice drinks too much. It simply says she 'had just drunk from a strange little bottle' and became smaller. The amount is not presented as a problem.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Alice does not lose the cake. She finds it 'in a small glass box under the table' and deliberately eats it. The cake is not lost.
differentiation_notes: Focuses on a specific detail in paragraph 1 that explains the cause-effect relationship of Alice's size problem, targeting RL.3.2's emphasis on key details rather than overall story recounting.
homogeneity_check: All choices are problems or situations Alice faces
specificity_check: All describe specific events or conditions
length_check: A:7 words, B:6 words, C:7 words, D:6 words - within 14% range
semantic_distance_check: Each describes a different type of problem with clear distinctions
single_correct_check: Only B is explicitly stated as the problem in paragraph 1

question: Which two events from different parts of the story show the same result?
option_1: Alice drinks the bottle and eats the mushroom - both make her normal size.
option_2: Alice eats the cake and grows tall - both help her reach the key.
option_3: Alice cries by the door and falls in the pool - both happen because she is sad.
option_4: The Rabbit drops his gloves and the Caterpillar gives advice - both help Alice.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. The bottle does not make Alice normal size. It makes her very small (ten inches tall). Only the mushroom helps her return to normal size at the end.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. These are the same event, not two different events. Alice eats the cake, which causes her to grow tall. Growing tall is the result of eating, not a separate event. Also, growing tall does not help her reach the key because she becomes too big for the door.
option_3_explanation: Correct. In paragraph 1, 'Alice felt so sad that she sat down and cried again' by the door. In paragraph 3, 'She fell into the pool of water she had made with her own tears.' Both crying events share the same cause (sadness) and contribute to the water pool, demonstrating how key details connect across sections.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The Rabbit dropping his gloves does not help Alice. He drops them because he is scared and runs away. While the Caterpillar does give advice, these events do not show the same result.
differentiation_notes: Requires connecting details across paragraphs 1-3 to identify repeated cause-effect pattern, emphasizing RL.3.2's focus on how key details convey meaning across text sections.

specificity_check: All describe concrete story events with proposed connections

single_correct_check: Only C correctly identifies two events with the genuinely same cause
diversity_check: Connects events across multiple paragraphs vs. reference asking about single final event

The White Rabbit was talking to himself. "Oh no! The Duchess will be so angry if I am late!" When Alice tried to talk to him, the Rabbit got scared. He dropped his gloves and fan and ran away quickly into the dark."Everything is so weird today!" said Alice. As she spoke, Alice noticed she was getting smaller again. Suddenly, splash! She fell into the pool of water she had made with her own tears. Poor Alice had to swim around in her own tear pool!"I wish I had not cried so much!" Alice said as she swam around looking for a way out. Alice was not the type of person to sit still and do nothing. After she got out of the pool, she decided to explore more of Wonderland.

---

Soon Alice found a large blue Caterpillar sitting on top of a mushroom. The Caterpillar was smoking a long pipe. Alice stood on her toes and looked over the edge of the mushroom. The Caterpillar and Alice stared at each other for a long time without saying anything.Finally, the Caterpillar took the pipe out of his mouth and asked, "Who are you?" Alice felt confused. "I do not really know, sir. I knew who I was this morning, but I have changed so many times today." The Caterpillar did not seem to understand Alice's problem with changing sizes.Before the Caterpillar crawled away, he told Alice something important. "One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter." Alice broke off a piece from each side of the mushroom. She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size.
question: According to the story, what lesson does Alice learn about trying to solve problems?
option_1: Always ask for help before trying anything yourself.
option_2: Give up quickly if the first try does not work.
option_3: Keep trying different solutions until you find what works.
option_4: Wait patiently and problems will solve themselves.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Alice does not ask for help to solve her size problems. She tries things on her own, like eating the cake and taking bites of the mushroom until she finds solutions.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. This is the opposite of what Alice does. She does not give up. Even after problems with the bottle and cake, she continues trying solutions like using the mushroom.
option_3_explanation: Correct. Throughout the story, Alice tries multiple solutions: drinking the bottle, eating the cake, and finally 'ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size' with the mushroom. The text shows her persistence in finding what works through trial and adjustment, which conveys the central message about problem-solving.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Alice does not wait for problems to solve themselves. She actively takes action by drinking, eating, and adjusting her approach until she succeeds.
differentiation_notes: Analyzes the central lesson conveyed through Alice's repeated attempts across all sections, requiring synthesis of her problem-solving pattern rather than recounting a single solution event.
homogeneity_check: All choices are problem-solving lessons or strategies
specificity_check: All are general advice statements about approaching problems
length_check: A:8 words, B:9 words, C:8 words, D:7 words - within 22% range
semantic_distance_check: Each represents a distinct problem-solving philosophy
single_correct_check: Only C is demonstrated through Alice's actual behavior pattern
diversity_check: Synthesizes thematic lesson from entire story vs. reference asking about specific final solution method

article_title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
passage_text:
Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
    
    
        Alice had just drunk from a strange little bottle. The liquid tasted very odd and made her feel funny."What a strange feeling!" said Alice. She was getting smaller and smaller. Soon, she was only ten inches tall. Now she was the perfect size to go through the tiny door to the beautiful garden. But when Alice got to the door, she realized something terrible. She had forgotten the little golden key on the table!Alice went back to get the key, but now she had a big problem. She was too short to reach the table! Alice sat down and started to cry. Then she noticed a small glass box under the table. Inside the box was a tiny cake with the words 'EAT ME' written on top with small pieces of fruit.

---

"I will eat this cake," Alice said with excitement. As soon as she took a bite, something amazing happened."How strange!" cried Alice. "Now I am growing bigger and bigger! I can barely see my feet!" Alice grew so tall that her head hit the ceiling of the hall. She was now nine feet tall! She quickly grabbed the golden key and ran to the garden door. But now she had the opposite problem. She was much too big to fit through the doorway. All she could do was look into the garden with one eye.Alice felt so sad that she sat down and cried again. She cried so many tears that they made a big pool of water around her. While she was crying, Alice heard footsteps. It was the White Rabbit coming back! He looked very fancy with white gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other hand.

---

The White Rabbit was talking to himself. "Oh no! The Duchess will be so angry if I am late!" When Alice tried to talk to him, the Rabbit got scared. He dropped his gloves and fan and ran away quickly into the dark."Everything is so weird today!" said Alice. As she spoke, Alice noticed she was getting smaller again. Suddenly, splash! She fell into the pool of water she had made with her own tears. Poor Alice had to swim around in her own tear pool!"I wish I had not cried so much!" Alice said as she swam around looking for a way out. Alice was not the type of person to sit still and do nothing. After she got out of the pool, she decided to explore more of Wonderland.

---

Soon Alice found a large blue Caterpillar sitting on top of a mushroom. The Caterpillar was smoking a long pipe. Alice stood on her toes and looked over the edge of the mushroom. The Caterpillar and Alice stared at each other for a long time without saying anything.Finally, the Caterpillar took the pipe out of his mouth and asked, "Who are you?" Alice felt confused. "I do not really know, sir. I knew who I was this morning, but I have changed so many times today." The Caterpillar did not seem to understand Alice's problem with changing sizes.Before the Caterpillar crawled away, he told Alice something important. "One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter." Alice broke off a piece from each side of the mushroom. She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size.
question: What key detail in the last paragraph shows that Alice finally has control over her size?
option_1: She breaks off pieces from both sides of the mushroom.
option_2: She eats tiny bites until reaching her normal size.
option_3: She stands on her toes to look at the Caterpillar.
option_4: The Caterpillar tells her which sides to use.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Breaking off pieces shows she has the tool, but not that she has control. Having the mushroom pieces is not the same as using them successfully to control her size.
option_2_explanation: Correct. The phrase 'ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size' shows Alice's careful, controlled approach. Unlike before when she drank or ate things that caused extreme changes, now she takes small bites and adjusts, demonstrating she has learned to control the process. This key detail conveys her success.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Standing on her toes happens before the Caterpillar gives advice. This detail shows Alice is still small and struggling, not that she has gained control.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The Caterpillar telling her information gives her knowledge, but does not show she has control. Control is shown through her actions, not through receiving advice.
differentiation_notes: Identifies the specific detail in paragraph 4 that demonstrates Alice's gained mastery, focusing on textual evidence of control rather than the method itself.
homogeneity_check: All choices are actions or events from the final paragraph
specificity_check: All describe specific textual details from the Caterpillar scene
length_check: A:10 words, B:9 words, C:9 words, D:8 words - within 20% range
semantic_distance_check: Each detail represents a different moment in the sequence
single_correct_check: Only B explicitly demonstrates Alice's careful control through action
diversity_check: Asks which detail shows control/mastery vs. reference asking what method Alice used

question: This story was most likely written to
option_1: entertain readers with a magical adventure.
option_2: help readers learn about animals.
option_3: teach readers about different types of food.
option_4: show readers how to solve problems.
option_1_explanation: You successfully identified the author’s purpose by recognizing the story uses make‑believe events to entertain. The text supports this with details like Alice “getting smaller and smaller,” then “growing bigger and bigger,” and meeting the White Rabbit and a Caterpillar “smoking a long pipe.” Remember: ask if the text gives facts, gives directions, or tells a fun, imaginary story—magic changes and talking animals are clues it’s meant to entertain.
option_2_explanation: You may have focused on the animals (the White Rabbit and the Caterpillar), but notice the text shows make-believe events—Alice shrinks and grows from a bottle, cake, and mushroom, and animals talk and wear gloves—so it isn’t teaching real facts about animals. The author’s purpose is to entertain readers with a magical adventure. Next time, ask yourself: Is this giving true facts or telling a pretend story about a character’s journey?
option_3_explanation: You may have focused on the “EAT ME” cake and thought it was about food, but the story shows magical events—Alice shrinks and grows, cries a pool of tears, and meets the White Rabbit and the Caterpillar. These make-believe adventures show the author wrote this to entertain readers with a magical adventure, not to teach about different foods. Strategy: Ask yourself, “Is this giving me facts to learn, or telling a fun, pretend story with characters and problems?”
option_4_explanation: You may have focused on Alice trying to fix her size and thought the author was showing how to solve problems, but notice the magic details—she shrinks and grows from a drink and cake, meets a talking White Rabbit and Caterpillar, and uses a magic mushroom—which show a make‑believe adventure meant to entertain. The correct answer is entertain readers with a magical adventure. Next time, ask, “Is this giving step-by-step directions or telling a fun story?” and choose the purpose that matches the whole passage.

question: The author most likely wrote this story to show readers that
option_1: strange adventures can happen when you explore new places.
option_2: crying will always make your problems worse.
option_3: animals can talk if you listen carefully.
option_4: eating unknown food is dangerous.
option_1_explanation: Correct. The author creates a fantastical world where Alice experiences unusual events (shrinking, growing, talking animals, pools of tears) after going through a door to explore. The narrative focus on these magical, impossible happenings reveals the author's purpose to present an imaginative adventure story rather than realistic instruction.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. While Alice's tears create a pool, the story does not present this as a lesson about crying making problems worse. Alice continues to succeed despite crying, and the author treats this as part of the fantastical adventure, not as a moral lesson.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Though animals talk in the story, the author does not present this as something readers should try. The talking animals are part of the fantasy world, not a lesson for readers about real life.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The story does not warn against eating unknown food. Alice successfully uses the cake and mushroom to solve problems. The author presents eating these items as part of the magical adventure, not as a danger to avoid.
differentiation_notes: Analyzes the author's overall narrative purpose across the entire passage, examining intent behind fantastical elements rather than genre classification.
homogeneity_check: All choices complete the stem about what the story shows readers
specificity_check: All are potential messages or lessons from the text
length_check: A:10 words, B:8 words, C:7 words, D:5 words - within 50% range, acceptable for meaning-based choices
semantic_distance_check: Each proposes a different type of message (adventure, consequence, animal behavior, safety)
single_correct_check: Only A aligns with the fantastical, adventure-focused narrative style
diversity_check: Examines author's message/theme vs. reference asking about entertainment purpose/genre

question: This passage differs from a realistic story because it
option_1: has a main character who faces challenges.
option_2: includes events that could never happen in real life.
option_3: describes a character's feelings and thoughts.
option_4: takes place in a location with rooms and doors.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Realistic stories also have main characters who face challenges. This is a common element in both realistic and fantasy stories, so it does not explain what makes this passage different from realistic fiction.
option_2_explanation: Correct. The passage includes impossible events like Alice shrinking to ten inches, growing to nine feet tall, talking animals, and magical food that changes body size. These fantastical elements distinguish this from realistic stories, which only include events that could actually happen. This demonstrates understanding of the fantasy genre's distinguishing features.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Realistic stories also describe characters' feelings and thoughts. The text 'Alice felt confused' and 'Alice felt so sad' are types of descriptions found in both realistic and fantasy stories.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Realistic stories can also take place in locations with rooms and doors. The setting having halls and doorways does not make the story unrealistic - it is what happens in those places (magical size changes) that creates the fantasy element.
differentiation_notes: Requires distinguishing fantasy from realistic fiction based on story elements throughout the passage, analyzing genre characteristics rather than entertainment purpose.
homogeneity_check: All choices are characteristics of the story/passage
specificity_check: All describe narrative elements or features
length_check: A:8 words, B:9 words, C:7 words, D:9 words - within 22% range
semantic_distance_check: Each describes a different story element (character, events, description, setting)
single_correct_check: Only B identifies the defining characteristic of fantasy genre
diversity_check: Asks about genre-defining elements vs. reference asking about overall writing purpose

question: What happens in paragraph 2 that changes how Alice sees her situation?
option_1: She notices the White Rabbit is carrying fancy items.
option_2: She realizes growing tall creates an opposite problem.
option_3: She discovers she can see into the garden now.
option_4: She learns that the Duchess is angry about something.

option_2_explanation: Correct. Paragraph 2 states 'But now she had the opposite problem. She was much too big to fit through the doorway.' This shows Alice's realization that growing tall (which seemed like a solution) actually created a new problem opposite to being too small. This moment reveals how each section builds with complications.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. While Alice can look into the garden with one eye, this is part of her problem, not a change in how she sees her situation. She still cannot enter the garden, which is what she wants.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Alice does not learn anything about the Duchess. The White Rabbit talks about the Duchess being angry, but this is his concern, not something that changes Alice's understanding of her own size problem.
differentiation_notes: Focuses on Alice's realization in paragraph 2 about problem progression, analyzing how one section creates new complications rather than examining overall story structure.
homogeneity_check: All choices are events or realizations from paragraph 2
specificity_check: All describe specific moments or discoveries

question: How does paragraph 3 connect to the problems Alice faced in earlier paragraphs?
option_1: It shows Alice solving all her earlier problems at once.
option_2: It introduces a completely new problem unrelated to size.
option_3: It shows a consequence of Alice's earlier size problem.
option_4: It repeats the exact same problem from paragraph 1.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Paragraph 3 does not show Alice solving her earlier problems. She is still dealing with size issues and now must swim in a tear pool. Her problems continue rather than being resolved.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. The problem in paragraph 3 (falling into the tear pool) is directly related to size. Alice fell in because she 'was getting smaller again' after growing too tall. The problem connects to her changing size throughout the story.
option_3_explanation: Correct. Paragraph 3 shows Alice falling into 'the pool of water she had made with her own tears' from paragraph 2 when she cried after being too big. This demonstrates how the text builds across sections - earlier actions (crying when too big) create new problems (the tear pool) that appear later, showing structural connection.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Paragraph 3 does not repeat paragraph 1's problem. In paragraph 1, Alice was too small to reach the table. In paragraph 3, she falls into a pool. These are different problems, though both relate to size changes.

article_title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
passage_text:
Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
    
    
        Alice had just drunk from a strange little bottle. The liquid tasted very odd and made her feel funny."What a strange feeling!" said Alice. She was getting smaller and smaller. Soon, she was only ten inches tall. Now she was the perfect size to go through the tiny door to the beautiful garden. But when Alice got to the door, she realized something terrible. She had forgotten the little golden key on the table!Alice went back to get the key, but now she had a big problem. She was too short to reach the table! Alice sat down and started to cry. Then she noticed a small glass box under the table. Inside the box was a tiny cake with the words 'EAT ME' written on top with small pieces of fruit.

---

"I will eat this cake," Alice said with excitement. As soon as she took a bite, something amazing happened."How strange!" cried Alice. "Now I am growing bigger and bigger! I can barely see my feet!" Alice grew so tall that her head hit the ceiling of the hall. She was now nine feet tall! She quickly grabbed the golden key and ran to the garden door. But now she had the opposite problem. She was much too big to fit through the doorway. All she could do was look into the garden with one eye.Alice felt so sad that she sat down and cried again. She cried so many tears that they made a big pool of water around her. While she was crying, Alice heard footsteps. It was the White Rabbit coming back! He looked very fancy with white gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other hand.

---

The White Rabbit was talking to himself. "Oh no! The Duchess will be so angry if I am late!" When Alice tried to talk to him, the Rabbit got scared. He dropped his gloves and fan and ran away quickly into the dark."Everything is so weird today!" said Alice. As she spoke, Alice noticed she was getting smaller again. Suddenly, splash! She fell into the pool of water she had made with her own tears. Poor Alice had to swim around in her own tear pool!"I wish I had not cried so much!" Alice said as she swam around looking for a way out. Alice was not the type of person to sit still and do nothing. After she got out of the pool, she decided to explore more of Wonderland.

---

Soon Alice found a large blue Caterpillar sitting on top of a mushroom. The Caterpillar was smoking a long pipe. Alice stood on her toes and looked over the edge of the mushroom. The Caterpillar and Alice stared at each other for a long time without saying anything.Finally, the Caterpillar took the pipe out of his mouth and asked, "Who are you?" Alice felt confused. "I do not really know, sir. I knew who I was this morning, but I have changed so many times today." The Caterpillar did not seem to understand Alice's problem with changing sizes.Before the Caterpillar crawled away, he told Alice something important. "One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter." Alice broke off a piece from each side of the mushroom. She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size.
question: How does each section of the story build on Alice's problem of changing sizes?
option_1: Each section shows Alice solving her size problems easily and quickly
option_2: Each section repeats the same problem without Alice learning anything new
option_3: Each section adds a new size change that creates bigger problems until she finds control
option_4: Each section shows Alice getting bigger, then smaller, then finding a solution
option_1_explanation: You may have focused on the times Alice tries to fix things, but the text shows it isn’t easy: she shrinks and can’t reach the key, then grows to nine feet and can’t fit through the door, cries a pool, and even shrinks into it. The correct idea is that each section adds a new size change that makes bigger problems until the Caterpillar explains the mushroom, and Alice uses tiny bites to control her size. Next time, reread what happens from beginning to end and pick the answer that fits the whole pattern, not just one moment.
option_2_explanation: You may have thought the story just repeats the same size problem, but it actually changes each time: first Alice is too small for the key, then too big for the door, and finally the Caterpillar tells her, “One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter,” and she eats tiny bites until she is back to normal. This shows each section adds a new size change that makes things harder until she learns to control her size. Next time, read from start to finish and ask, “How does the problem change, and what does the character learn?”
option_3_explanation: You successfully recognized the sequence and cause-and-effect by seeing how each part shows Alice’s size change creating a new problem until she gains control. The text shows this: “she was only ten inches tall… had forgotten the little golden key,” then “I am growing bigger and bigger… much too big to fit through the doorway,” and later the Caterpillar says, “One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller,” which helps her get back to normal. Remember to track what happens first, next, and last, and ask, “What new problem does this change cause?” when you read similar stories.
option_4_explanation: You may have looked for a repeating pattern, but the text shows first Alice gets smaller and can’t reach the key, then she grows too big and even shrinks into her tear pool, and only in the last part the Caterpillar’s mushroom helps her control her size. This means each part adds a new size change that causes bigger problems until she learns control—not “bigger, then smaller, then solution” each time. Next time, reread each part and check that your answer matches what actually happens in all parts, not a pattern you expect.

option_1: She tastes them first before eating the whole thing.
option_2: She finds them in boxes with written instructions.
option_3: They cause her body size to change each time.

option_2_explanation: Incorrect. Only the cake was in a box with 'EAT ME' written on it. The bottle from earlier (Part I) and the mushroom do not have written instructions or come in boxes. This is not a pattern throughout the story.
option_3_explanation: Correct. Every food or drink Alice consumes causes size changes: the bottle makes her shrink to ten inches, the cake makes her grow to nine feet, and 'One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter.' This consistent pattern occurs multiple times, showing how this problem repeats throughout successive parts.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The foods do not always taste sweet or make Alice feel better. The bottle 'tasted very odd' (not sweet), and after eating the cake she 'felt so sad that she sat down and cried' because she became too big. They cause problems, not improvement.

question: In paragraph 1, Alice experiences a problem that happens again later in the story. What is this repeating problem?
option_1: She cannot open doors because they are locked.
option_2: She forgets where she placed important items.
option_3: Her size prevents her from doing what she wants.
option_4: She cannot find the right food to eat.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. The doors are not locked. The problem is size-related: Alice is too small to reach the key (paragraph 1) and too big to fit through the doorway (paragraph 2). The door itself is not locked - she has access issues due to size.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. Alice does not forget where items are located. In paragraph 1, she 'realized' she had 'forgotten the little golden key on the table' - meaning she left it there, not that she forgot its location. She knows exactly where the key is.
option_3_explanation: Correct. The pattern of size preventing Alice from achieving goals repeats multiple times: too small to reach the table (paragraph 1), too big to fit through the door (paragraph 2), small enough to fall in the pool (paragraph 3). Each section shows her size creating obstacles to what she wants to do, demonstrating this recurring problem throughout successive parts.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Alice finds food when she needs it - the cake under the table and later the mushroom. The problem is not finding food, but rather the unpredictable effects food has on her size.
differentiation_notes: Asks students to identify the abstract problem concept (size limitation) that recurs across multiple sections, rather than the specific manifestation (growing/shrinking).

question: In the story, which problem happens to Alice more than once?
option_1: She grows and shrinks over and over after eating or drinking.
option_2: She keeps losing her shoes.
option_3: She keeps getting locked out of her house.
option_4: She keeps turning invisible whenever she talks.
option_1_explanation: Great job! You successfully identified a pattern and key details by noticing that Alice changes size whenever she eats or drinks. The text shows this when it says, “She was getting smaller and smaller” after the bottle, “Now I am growing bigger and bigger!” after the cake, and the Caterpillar explains, “One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter.” Remember to look for repeated events and cause-and-effect clues (like what happens after she eats or drinks) when answering similar questions.
option_2_explanation: You may have focused on the line “I can barely see my feet” and turned it into “losing shoes,” but the story never mentions shoes. Instead, it shows a pattern: she shrinks after drinking from the bottle, grows huge after eating the “EAT ME” cake, and later changes size again by eating mushroom pieces. So the correct answer is that she grows and shrinks over and over after eating or drinking. Next time, reread for exact words and look for events that repeat to find the main idea.
option_3_explanation: You may have focused on the door mix-up and thought she was locked out of a house. But the story says she “was getting smaller,” the cake made her “growing bigger and bigger,” later she was “getting smaller again,” and the Caterpillar explains the mushroom can make her taller or shorter. This shows the main thing that keeps happening is her size changing after she eats or drinks, which is why the correct answer is that she grows and shrinks over and over. Tip: look for what happens again and again to find the best answer.
option_4_explanation: You may have thought the line “as she spoke” meant she turned invisible, but the text says she is “getting smaller and smaller” and later “growing bigger and bigger”—it never says she disappears. The correct answer is that Alice keeps shrinking and growing after she eats or drinks (bottle, cake, mushroom). Next time, reread for the exact words that tell what changes (smaller, bigger, grow, shrink) and make sure your answer matches those words.

article_title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
passage_text:
Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
    
    
        Alice had just drunk from a strange little bottle. The liquid tasted very odd and made her feel funny."What a strange feeling!" said Alice. She was getting smaller and smaller. Soon, she was only ten inches tall. Now she was the perfect size to go through the tiny door to the beautiful garden. But when Alice got to the door, she realized something terrible. She had forgotten the little golden key on the table!Alice went back to get the key, but now she had a big problem. She was too short to reach the table! Alice sat down and started to cry. Then she noticed a small glass box under the table. Inside the box was a tiny cake with the words 'EAT ME' written on top with small pieces of fruit.

---

"I will eat this cake," Alice said with excitement. As soon as she took a bite, something amazing happened."How strange!" cried Alice. "Now I am growing bigger and bigger! I can barely see my feet!" Alice grew so tall that her head hit the ceiling of the hall. She was now nine feet tall! She quickly grabbed the golden key and ran to the garden door. But now she had the opposite problem. She was much too big to fit through the doorway. All she could do was look into the garden with one eye.Alice felt so sad that she sat down and cried again. She cried so many tears that they made a big pool of water around her. While she was crying, Alice heard footsteps. It was the White Rabbit coming back! He looked very fancy with white gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other hand.

---

The White Rabbit was talking to himself. "Oh no! The Duchess will be so angry if I am late!" When Alice tried to talk to him, the Rabbit got scared. He dropped his gloves and fan and ran away quickly into the dark."Everything is so weird today!" said Alice. As she spoke, Alice noticed she was getting smaller again. Suddenly, splash! She fell into the pool of water she had made with her own tears. Poor Alice had to swim around in her own tear pool!"I wish I had not cried so much!" Alice said as she swam around looking for a way out. Alice was not the type of person to sit still and do nothing. After she got out of the pool, she decided to explore more of Wonderland.

---

Soon Alice found a large blue Caterpillar sitting on top of a mushroom. The Caterpillar was smoking a long pipe. Alice stood on her toes and looked over the edge of the mushroom. The Caterpillar and Alice stared at each other for a long time without saying anything.Finally, the Caterpillar took the pipe out of his mouth and asked, "Who are you?" Alice felt confused. "I do not really know, sir. I knew who I was this morning, but I have changed so many times today." The Caterpillar did not seem to understand Alice's problem with changing sizes.Before the Caterpillar crawled away, he told Alice something important. "One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter." Alice broke off a piece from each side of the mushroom. She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size.
question: What happens multiple times in the story that shows Alice has not learned to control her size yet?
option_1: She eats or drinks something and her size changes unexpectedly.
option_2: She asks other characters for help with her problems.
option_3: She runs away when she sees talking animals.
option_4: She loses items she needs to solve her problems.
option_1_explanation: Correct. This pattern repeats showing lack of control: Alice drinks the bottle and shrinks unexpectedly to ten inches (paragraph 1), eats the cake and 'Now I am growing bigger and bigger!' in surprise (paragraph 2), and only gains control when she 'ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size' with the mushroom (paragraph 4). The repeated unexpected changes demonstrate her lack of control until the final section.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. Alice does not ask others for help multiple times. She tries to talk to the White Rabbit once (he runs away), and she speaks with the Caterpillar once (who gives advice). She does not repeatedly seek help - she mostly tries to solve problems herself.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Alice does not run away from talking animals. When she meets the White Rabbit and Caterpillar, she tries to communicate with them. It is the White Rabbit who runs away from Alice, not the other way around.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Alice does not repeatedly lose items. She forgets the key on the table once in paragraph 1, but this does not happen multiple times. After that, she successfully grabs the key when tall enough.
differentiation_notes: Examines the repetition that demonstrates Alice's developing mastery (or lack thereof) across sections, focusing on evidence of learning progress.
homogeneity_check: All choices are recurring actions or events
specificity_check: All describe repeatable behaviors or occurrences
length_check: A:10 words, B:8 words, C:7 words, D:7 words - within 30% range
semantic_distance_check: Each describes distinctly different types of repeated actions
single_correct_check: Only A describes an action that occurs multiple times showing lack of control
diversity_check: Focuses on what repetition reveals about character development vs. reference simply asking what specific thing happens multiple times

question: Which detail from the story shows that Alice's size changes continue to surprise her?
option_1: 'What a strange feeling!' said Alice.
option_2: 'How strange!' cried Alice.
option_3: 'Everything is so weird today!' said Alice.
option_4: 'I wish I had not cried so much!' Alice said.
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. This quote appears when Alice first drinks from the bottle and begins shrinking. While it shows surprise, the question asks about her size changes continuing to surprise her, which means ongoing surprise across multiple changes, not just the first one.
option_2_explanation: Correct. This exclamation occurs in paragraph 2 when Alice grows tall after eating the cake: 'How strange!' cried Alice. 'Now I am growing bigger and bigger!' This shows that even after experiencing shrinking earlier, she is still surprised by size changes, demonstrating the pattern continues. Her continued surprise across multiple sections reveals she hasn't anticipated or controlled these changes.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. This quote from paragraph 3 refers to all the weird events of the day generally, not specifically to her surprise about size changes. It is about overall strangeness, not about her reaction to changing size.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. This quote shows Alice's regret about crying and creating the pool, not her surprise about size changes. It expresses a different emotion (regret) about a different problem (the tear pool).
differentiation_notes: Requires identifying which specific quote evidences ongoing surprise about size changes across sections, analyzing character response patterns.
homogeneity_check: All choices are direct quotes from Alice in the story
specificity_check: All are brief exclamations or statements by Alice
length_check: A:6 words, B:4 words, C:6 words, D:8 words - within 50% range, acceptable for quotes
semantic_distance_check: Each quote expresses different emotions or reactions in different contexts
single_correct_check: Only B is explicitly about surprise at size change happening again
diversity_check: Asks for textual evidence of continued surprise vs. reference asking what action/event repeats multiple times

question: Based on paragraphs 1-3, which event keeps creating new problems for Alice?
option_1: meeting unusual talking animals
option_2: changing to different sizes
option_3: exploring new rooms in the hall
option_4: trying to help the White Rabbit
option_1_explanation: Incorrect. Meeting animals does not create problems for Alice. The White Rabbit runs away without causing problems for her, and the Caterpillar actually helps by telling her about the mushroom. The animals do not create her difficulties.
option_2_explanation: Correct. Each size change creates a new problem: Shrinking means she cannot reach the key (paragraph 1), growing means she cannot fit through the door (paragraph 2), and shrinking again causes her to fall in the tear pool (paragraph 3). This pattern shows how one event (changing size) repeatedly generates obstacles across successive sections of the story.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. Alice does not explore new rooms in paragraphs 1-3. She stays in the same hall dealing with the door and the table. Her problems come from size changes in one location, not from exploring different rooms.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. Alice does not try to help the White Rabbit. She tries to talk to him once, but he runs away. She is focused on her own problems (getting through the door), not on helping the Rabbit with his concerns about the Duchess.
differentiation_notes: Identifies the causal event that generates multiple problems across sections 1-3, analyzing what drives the problem sequence.
homogeneity_check: All choices are events or actions from the story
specificity_check: All describe activities or occurrences
length_check: A:4 words, B:4 words, C:5 words, D:5 words - within 20% range
semantic_distance_check: Each describes a different type of recurring event or action
single_correct_check: Only B identifies the event that creates problems in each of the three paragraphs
diversity_check: Asks what event causes multiple problems vs. reference asking what problem happens multiple times

question: The author includes the detail about Alice swimming in her own tears to show
option_1: how Alice's earlier actions lead to later consequences.
option_2: that Alice enjoys swimming in unusual places.
option_3: why Alice should never cry about her problems.
option_4: when Alice learned to control her emotions better.
option_1_explanation: Correct. This detail connects paragraph 2 (where Alice cries so much 'they made a big pool of water') to paragraph 3 (where 'She fell into the pool of water she had made with her own tears'). The author deliberately links these sections to show cause and effect - Alice's crying in one part creates a problem she must face in the next part, demonstrating how successive parts build on earlier ones.
option_2_explanation: Incorrect. Alice does not enjoy swimming in the pool. The text says 'Poor Alice had to swim around' and 'I wish I had not cried so much!' These show discomfort and regret, not enjoyment of unusual swimming.
option_3_explanation: Incorrect. The author does not present a lesson about never crying. Alice successfully continues her adventure despite crying. The tear pool is part of the fantastical story, not a moral lesson against crying.
option_4_explanation: Incorrect. The tear pool incident does not show Alice learning to control emotions. She continues to experience strong feelings throughout the story. The detail is about the consequence of her tears, not about emotional control or learning.
differentiation_notes: Analyzes the author's structural purpose for including a specific detail that connects sections, examining why the author made compositional choices.
homogeneity_check: All choices explain why the author included the tear pool detail
specificity_check: All propose authorial purposes or messages
length_check: A:8 words, B:7 words, C:7 words, D:7 words - within 12% range
semantic_distance_check: Each proposes a different authorial purpose (structure, character preference, moral lesson, character development)
single_correct_check: Only A accurately identifies the structural connection purpose
diversity_check: Examines author's structural linking purpose vs. reference asking what specific event repeats
